content.image_caption: séverine. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **séverine** is the moniker of multidisciplinary artist Christiane Øyen.

Born and raised in Long Beach California, her work traverses the familiar and the far-flung — absorbing and sublimating sounds and sensations from deep within and high above. Released in 2022, _Dawn of the Coastal DJ_ is a collection of precisely calibrated club concoctions — each track seeing disparate soundworlds fission and fuse like research chemicals combining to form new consciousness-warping compounds. From euphoric trance and sleazy electroclash, to cerebral techno intertwined with gratuitous club bangers, one can always expect to hear at least one poptimistic dancefloor-ready blend within her set. séverine leads DIY rave collective Xtended Release, an LA-based party that has paired local talent alongside international artists including Dis Fig, DJ G2G, Jasmine Infiniti and Ariel Zetina.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/s3v3r1n333)

content.image_caption: Ausschuss. Photo by Ellie Lizbeth Brown.

content.text_block: Marked by mesmeric forays into experimental production and challenging soundscapes, the music of **Ausschuss** seeks to reshape the club — not simply as a dancefloor — but as a space to inhabit.

Emerging in 2014 through a series of self-releases, bootlegs and a residency on Berlin Community Radio, Ausschuss’ expansive approach has seen him perform in venues such as Berghain and Macao Milan alongside working with labels like CANVAS and Perpetual Care. A member of London label Circadian Rhythms, following the release of his debut EP _Room1_ in 2018, Ausschuss has expanded his practice through scoring and composition work, contributing mixes for the likes of CXEMA, AFFXWRKS and Berlin's Leisure Systems. Ausschuss released _Cruise_ on MAL Recordings in 2021.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/ausschuss)

content.image_caption: Akiko Haruna. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Akiko Haruna** is a producer, vocalist and performer who manipulates sound and rhythm into personal, playful and cathartic forms.

A background in experimental dance and mixed-media composition, Haruna bends and breaks these disciplines throughout their productions, pushing at the boundaries of raucous pop, club-ready percussion, dense electronics and expansive soundscapes with euphoria and poise. Haruna’s debut EP _Be Little Me_, which they wrote, recorded, produced, and mixed, was released in late 2021. Potent and visceral, these tracks marry dance music and elastic sound design with Haruna’s consciously DIY approach, anchored in meditations on gender, race and heritage.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/akikoharuna)

content.image_caption: Kai Whiston. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Kai Whiston** is a music producer and multidisciplinary artist, specialising in romanticism, amplified world building and post-genre sound design.

Having previously worked with artists such as Shygirl, Dorian Electra, Pussy Riot, Iglooghost and Clarence Clarity among others, in 2019 Whiston’s released two studio albums, both arriving to critical acclaim. Based in London, Whiston released his newest album _Quiet As Kept, F.O.G._ in 2022: part-celebration, part-critique, part-reality, and part-fantasy; sonically, Whiston’s album offers a versatile and deeply original take on dance music. Tracks are threaded together with live string quartets arranged by Whiston and recorded at Air Studios, juxtaposed against otherworldly sound design that bring a cinematic intensity to the work.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/kaiwhiston)

content.image_caption: april222. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: Beginning their career as a producer, **april222**'s love affair with music centres on genres pioneered by black artists, including Jersey club, rap, hiphop, RnB and afrobeat.

In this sense, they regard their practice as a DJ as a testament to the beauty of black art, engaging their audiences with a rigorous yet enrapturing journey through the black sonic canon. A collector for many years, april222's library is a true digger's paradise, full of hidden gems, fascinating oddities and dancefloor magic.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/lxrxba)

content.image_caption: Soda Plains. Photo by Ellie Lizbeth Brown.

content.text_block: Originally from Hong Kong by way of the British West Midlands, **Soda Plains** is an enigmatic and mysterious figure.

What's for certain is that his 2022 EP _Living With Elvis_ is visionary – six tracks that take up elements of 1990s trance and breakbeat, marrying euphoric vocals with dizzying drops and lithe percussion. His tight production skills are brought over to the decks, where he ties together theatrical melodies and deconstructed sonic textures. Take his 2016 Boileroom breakout set – full of orchestral interludes and bass-heavy polyrhythms, Soda Plains knows how to keep things surreal and spectacular.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/sodaplains)

content.image_caption: Async Figure. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Async Figure** is a collaboration between London and Glasgow based artists **MM** & **Suda**.

The project picks up where their label Her Records left off, wrenching meaning and honesty from the most absurd trance-inflected chords and arpeggios. The duo recorded a mix featuring 18 of their own productions at Unsound Festival in 2018, which led to a tour of China the following year. They continued to build new tracks in secret at a restless pace, the first three of which were revealed in 2021 on their debut release for Tzusing’s Shanghai-based label Sea Cucumber.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/asyncfigure)

content.image_caption: Soft Break. Photo by Sydney Rahimtoola.

content.text_block: Rotterdam based **Soft Break** is a DJ and multidisciplinary designer.

Heavily influenced by early encounters with the city's jungle, dubstep and grime scene, her sets soar to 160 bpm, moving through gentle vocals, techno, footwork and hip-hop to sub-destroying bass. A graduate of the No Shade DJ Mentoring Program 2020 in Berlin, during the same year, the DJ collective AMPFEMININE was born, of which Soft Break has become a vital force and figurehead. Setting out to arouse creatives lurking in the darker corners of Rotterdam, AMPFEMININE aims to platform both the colour and feminine energy lacking within contemporary club culture. No stranger to Sonic Acts, where she works as a curator, Yessica Deira is also a tutor at the Sandberg Instituut and Design Academy Eindhoven. Manifesting a keen awareness of politics and ethical sensibilities towards diversifying dancefloors, while (re)telling stories of blackness and black Dutch identities, Soft Break's powerful presence reverberates throughout the Netherlands and further afield.
[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/softbreak)

content.image_caption: Enrico Malatesta. Photo by Chiara Pavolucci.

content.text_block: **Enrico Malatesta** is an Italian percussionist and sound researcher active in the fields of experimental music, sound intervention and performance.

His practice explores the relations between sound, space and body, the vitality of materials and the morphology of surfaces with particular attention to percussive acts, touch based-perception, and modes of listening. Since 2007 Malatesta has presented his work with tours across Europe, Brazil, South Korea, Japan, UK, North America and Russia, and has performed in festivals and special events in venues such as Pirelli HangarBicocca in Milan, Berghain in Berlin, and MAM in Rio de Janeiro.

[Website](https://enricomalatesta.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/_enricomalatesta_/)

attributes.title: Enrico Malatesta & Tomoko Sauvage Sound Walk

content.image_caption: Tomoko Sauvage. Photo by Leo Lopez.

content.text_block: **Tomoko Sauvage** is a musician and sound artist best known for her experiments with hybrid instruments combining water, ceramics, sub-aquatic amplification and electronics.

Her research is grounded in live-performance practices that embrace the unpredictable dynamics of materials. Incorporating ritualistic gestures, she playfully improvises with environments, using chance as a compositional method. Her performances and installations have been presented at RIBOCA, V&A Museum, Manifesta, Roskilde Festival, Sharjah Art Foundation, Centre Pompidou Metz and Nyege Nyege Festival, among others. Recorded in a water tank in Berlin, utilising self-invented ‘natural synthesisers’: porcelain and glass bowls, filled with liquid and amplified by hydrophones, her third solo album _Fischgeist_ was released in 2020. Sauvage lives and works in Paris.
[Website](https://o-o-o-o.org/)

content.image_caption: Louis Braddock Clarke at Night Air: Melting Cores, OT301 on 31 March 2022. Photo by Pieter Kers.

content.text_block: **Louis Braddock Clarke** works as researcher and creative practitioner interpreting notions from domains of art, geography, physics and philosophy.

His multi-disciplinary  approach unfolds as an experimental inquiry blending together scientific and conceptual theories. Seeking out concealed obscurities lurking in daily life, he utilises cartographic language, new materialist thought and modes of peripheral vision. Braddock Clarke’s relationship with the geographical arts is embedded in his formative years in Cornwall, UK where he was surrounded by moorlands, granite, shifting isolines, tin mines and trans-Atlantic cable systems. These Earth energies have become paramount to his ongoing research methods relating to technologies and terrains. In their collaborative project _Out of Focus_, Braddock Clarke and Zuzanna Zgierska seek to interpret notions of research, design, philosophy and science.

[Website](https://louisbraddockclarke.co.uk/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/louisbclarke/)

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Zuzanna Zgierska. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Zuzanna Zgierska** is a cross-media designer with a strong interest in media theory.

he makes science-fiction objects, which challenge the tender interfaces between the human and the technical. Her research invites to view technology in a non-hierarchical, non-binary way: beyond the cold tokens of 0 and 1. Zgierska has exhibited worldwide, and her visual and written work has been published in an array of design magazines. In their multi-disciplinary project _Out of Focus_, Zgierska and Louis Braddock Clarke seek to interpret notions of research, design, philosophy and science. Unless caught red-handed hacking a bean sorting machine, Zgierska can be found extruding screen surfaces into portions of edible substance or chasing lightning storms across industrial deserts.

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Andrea Galano Toro. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Andrea Galano Toro** is a graphic designer and artist with a focus on research and storytelling.

She was born in Spain and raised in Chile, and is currently based in Berlin. She is interested in how site-specific work can emerge from a feeling of displacement. Following her interest, Andrea Galano Toro began to tell stories through the exploration of traces and their materiality. These stories are told through voices of objects, monuments, land, mountains, sand, and water, finding their form mostly in video installations and publications. She is also busy writing spells and exploring raw worlds with her research collaborator Laila Saber Rodriguez, as part of their collective Cruda.

[Website](https://andreagalanotoro.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/andygalano/)

content.image_caption: Seline Buttner. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Seline Buttner’s** practice is centred around an intuitive encounter with the world – incorporating theory, fieldwork, documentation methods, and material development.

As an interdisciplinary artist, researcher, and designer, she works with installations, videos, textile, and generative visuals. She explores how technological innovation and productivity both characterise and dominate our environment, our behaviour and our bodies. Buttner creates sensorial experiences which question the complex ways humans perceive, act upon and are entangled with their intertwined environments. She received her degree in Graphic Design in 2017 and graduated from ArtEZ’s Design, Art & Technology department in 2021.

[Website](http://selinebuttner.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/seline.buttner/?hl=de)

content.image_caption: MELT. Photo courtesy of the Artists.

content.text_block: **MELT** (**Loren Britton** & **Isabel Paehr**) are arts-design researchers who work together on games, technology and critical pedagogy.

Investigating the political and material conditions of technological infrastructures, they re-distribute agency through methods of queer play, unlearning and leaking. Their work crumbles structures, unbinds materials, dissolves technology and makes collectivities, often taking the form of video art and workshops. MELT are influenced by (melting) ice, freezers, software, signals, moving too fast/slow, Wendy Hui Kyong Chun, Denise Ferreira Da Silva, digital materialism, post-/de-colonial thinking, GIFs, climate protests, anti-racism and dancing. 

_Meltionary_ (derived from dictionary), is a growing collection of arts-design-research engagements that cooks up questions around material transformations alongside impulses from trans* feminism and Disability Justice. Melting as a kaleidoscope-like phenomena touches upon multiple topics at once: climate change, the potential for political reformulations, change over time and material transformation.

[Website](www.meltionary.com)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/meltionary/?hl=fr)

Walking In the Midst of It All
Walking In the Midst of It All

content.text_block: # EXHIBITION

Expanding from Sonic Acts' long term research focus on the implications of climate crisis, _one sun after another_ traces the inextricable nature of pollution and time. Unfolding in several places, the exhibition and its public programme of events engage with ecology across vast scales.

Taking its name from a poem in Etel Adnan’s powerful book _The Arab Apocalypse_ (1989), the biennial exhibition gestures toward the passing of time, but also carries traces of _Bhagavad Gita_, referenced by Robert Oppenheimer after witnessing the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ‘If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst at once into the sky, that would be like the splendour of the mighty one. I am become Death, The Shatterer of Worlds.’ Drawing upon this sublime, all-subsuming vision, one sun after another attends to slow, accumulative violence as it makes its imprint on futures yet to come. Touching on deep, real, geological time, the programme embraces nonlinearity, fluctuation and porousness, making space for leaks. Permeable to hope, the figure of the ever-dawning sun glows without burning, permeating warmth, fueling imagination and propagating life.

content.image_caption: _Gauge_, Danny Osborne, Patrick Thompson, Alexa Hatanaka, Sarah McNair-Landry, Eric McNair-Landry, Erik Boomer, and Raven Chacon. Photo by Erik Boomer.

content.text_block: Contemplating multiple incarnations of time, _one sun after another_ listens to an immersive aerial choir of bees, follows a microbe embedded within lithium traveling from a Chilean mine to a digital device, and plunges into deep time through lead-encased nuclear coconuts from the Bikini Atoll. Artistic research traces the lineages of exhaust produced by oil and other extractive economies, while in other places it speculates over Greenland’s mineral deposits, now made accessible by melting ice. In the Canadian Arctic, visual narratives on monumental ice walls come and go with tidal movements, soundtracked by a cacophony of environmental field recordings. Against the din, visitors are welcome to a joyful meditation about presence, sensing and bending time, before drifting downstream, where the exhibition stretches time even further. Diving under, performative and installative artworks explore toxic cycles of water and stretch inner time with hybrid instruments and sub-aquatic amplification.

## PUBLIC PROGRAMME

The exhibition is complimented by a public programme of a variety of events, emanating across W139 and Zone2Source in Amsterdam. Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.
→ [Find out more about the public programme](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/public-programme)

content.image_caption: Cesar Majorana. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Cesar Majorana** is a performer, presenter and artist working with writing, video and fragrance.

His work explores themes of digital media, internet culture, metaphor and memory; playfully rupturing the distance between artwork and viewer. Majorana graduated from Sandberg Institute in 2021 and his work has been on display at NPO3, Van Gogh Museum, IFFR and Rijksmuseum.

[Instagram ](https://www.instagram.com/cesarforever/)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/cesarforever)

l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block:
_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

→ [Read through the Inner Ear(th) programme here](https://pdfhost.io/v/iUue4sUGj_Inner_Earth_Programme) (PDF)

→ [View the Het HEM floorplan here](https://cms.sonicacts.com/public/uploads/SA_HEM_cover_V06_copy_2_bd2ef4c55d.jpg?w=1920&q=75)

content.text_block: Getting our hands, eyes and ears dirty, _Practicum_ is a collaborative workshop series organised by Sonic Acts that focuses on applied knowledge, making from research and learning together.

These gatherings are artist-led and emphasise collaborative, hands-on learning: attuning and creating together in ways that entangle modes of perception, production and knowledge-creation. 

Continuing from our yearly programme, _Practicum_ resumes in full force for Sonic Acts Biennial 2022, welcoming artists, performers and researchers from across our exhibition, sound art, and symposium programmes. Each workshop features a separate open call with a different set of parameters.

attributes.title: From Listening to Sampling: IMC Weekendshool Workshop
l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block:
Welcome to [l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/l-a-g)!

Soundcamp collective and radio artist Kate Donovan host an open radio space and workshop-hub at the Homebase in Het HEM, with microphone and transistor building, dusk listening and fieldwalks, tuning to live sounds of the site.

**Tune into the 58 hour-long broadcast online via the play button at the top of sonicacts.com from Friday 7 October to Sunday 9 October.** The transmission is aired from the Homebase situated in the central hall of Het HEM, the Huiskamer and at various movable listening points dispersed around the Hembrug site.

_l a g_ occurs as an unpredictable ghost in the live archive of streams, as sounds move and appear out of place. lt brings stutters, drops or echoes that can put us into close contact with both what just occured and is about to.

# Contribute your own! Join in the stream below:

content.url: <iframe id="irc" height="500px" width="756px" frameborder="0" border="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="default" src="https://irc.soundtent.org/?&theme=soundcamp_irc_v1_white#acousticommons"></iframe>

content.text_block: The Soundcamp programme has been devised and curated specially for the Sonic Acts Biennial.

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block: **Soundcamp** is an arts cooperative based in London, Crete and The Hague, working on transmission ecologies ranging from DIY broadcasting devices to public sound and radio projects.

As part of the Acoustic Commons network, Soundcamp coordinates the long-form radio broadcast Reveil, in addition to an annual series of sound and ecology events on Dawn Chorus. In 2020, Soundcamp initiated the Creative Europe small cooperation project: _Acoustic Commons_, in partnership with arts organisations in Europe and Japan. Recent projects include _As if radio.._ at COP26 Glasgow, _Meet Me On The Radio_, _Biosphere Open Microphones_, and the portable audio system _PITCH_. With expertise in environmental sound, transmission art and participatory technologies, Soundcamp regularly organises workshops and exchanges as part of a socially engaged practice.
[Website](https://soundtent.org/soundcamp_about.html)

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.image_caption: Kate Donovan. Photo by Bryan Zimmerman.

content.text_block: **Kate Donovan** is a Berlin-based artist, researcher and facilitator working with radio, listening and the more-than-human.

In her collaborative radio practice, Donovan is a member of CoLaboRadio, Datscha Radio, and the international feminist group Shortwave Collective. She has made work for radio stations, art organisations and festivals across the world, and her writing appears in online and print publications, including _Versorgerin_, _Explore Dance_, _Fusion_, and _Seismograf_. content.text_block: Getting our hands, eyes and ears dirty, _Practicum_ is a collaborative workshop series organised by Sonic Acts that focuses on applied knowledge, making from research and learning together.

These gatherings are artist-led and emphasise collaborative, hands-on learning: attuning and creating together in ways that entangle modes of perception, production and knowledge-creation. 

Continuing from our yearly programme, _Practicum_ resumes in full force for Sonic Acts Biennial 2022, welcoming artists, performers and researchers from across our exhibition, sound art, and symposium programmes. Each workshop features a separate open call with a different set of parameters.

content.text_block: **Soundcamp** is an arts cooperative based in London, Crete and The Hague, working on transmission ecologies ranging from DIY broadcasting devices to public sound and radio projects.

As part of the Acoustic Commons network, Soundcamp coordinates the long-form radio broadcast Reveil, in addition to an annual series of sound and ecology events on Dawn Chorus. In 2020, Soundcamp initiated the Creative Europe small cooperation project: _Acoustic Commons_, in partnership with arts organisations in Europe and Japan. Recent projects include _As if radio.._ at COP26 Glasgow, _Meet Me On The Radio_, _Biosphere Open Microphones_, and the portable audio system _PITCH_. With expertise in environmental sound, transmission art and participatory technologies, Soundcamp regularly organises workshops and exchanges as part of a socially engaged practice.

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.image_caption: John Grzinich recording sound in Wadi Rum, Jordan. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: As part of his practice, artist and cultural coordinator **John Grzinich** draws together sound, moving images, site-specificity and collaborative social structures.

Composing, performing and exhibiting since the mid 1990s, the focus of his work in recent years has been to combine sonic encounters and listening practices with various media. The resulting audio-centric works seek to challenge ingrained anthropocentric perceptions of terrestrial existence, discovering ways of attuning differently to landscapes and non-human entities. In addition to an impressive array of composition recordings, Grzinich’s work has resulted innumerous performances and projects throughout Europe and the US. Grzinich coordinates activities for the artist-run organisation MoKS and is currently a visiting Associate Professor at the Estonian Academy of Arts.

[Website](https://maaheli.ee/main/)

[Bandcamp](https://maaheli.bandcamp.com/)

l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.image_caption: Lance Laoyan. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Lance Gapuz Laoyan** is a sound artist and researcher.

His work considers different sonic ecologies within an environment, asking how they are perceived through the act of listening. Through the application of listening methodologies and recording technologies, Laoyan engages in site specific environments marked by noise pollution. This approach towards noise enables Laoyan to position himself within, and to pay close attention to, undesired sounds within a landscape. He is drawn to this re-positioning of human listening to question the politics of noise and its relation to animal species within the natural environment. Laoyan holds a BA in Graphic Design from Manchester School of Art and in 2021 Laoyan completed a Master’s as part of the Non-Linear Narrative course at the Royal Academy of Arts in The Hague. Laoyan has presented his work at festivals across the Netherlands and attended Sonic Act’s FieldArts panel in July, 2022.

[Website](https://lancelaoyan.co.uk/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/lance-laoyan)

l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.image_caption: Lance Laoyan. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Lance Gapuz Laoyan** is a sound artist and researcher.

His work considers different sonic ecologies within an environment, asking how they are perceived through the act of listening. Through the application of listening methodologies and recording technologies, Laoyan engages in site specific environments marked by noise pollution. This approach towards noise enables Laoyan to position himself within, and to pay close attention to, undesired sounds within a landscape. He is drawn to this re-positioning of human listening to question the politics of noise and its relation to animal species within the natural environment. Laoyan holds a BA in Graphic Design from Manchester School of Art and in 2021 Laoyan completed a Master’s as part of the Non-Linear Narrative course at the Royal Academy of Arts in The Hague. Laoyan has presented his work at festivals across the Netherlands and attended Sonic Act’s FieldArts panel in July, 2022.

[Website](https://lancelaoyan.co.uk/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/lance-laoyan)

attributes.title: Walking In the Midst of It All
Walking In the Midst of It All

content.text_block:
_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

→ [Read through the Inner Ear(th) programme here](https://pdfhost.io/v/iUue4sUGj_Inner_Earth_Programme) (PDF)

→ [View the Het HEM floorplan here](https://cms.sonicacts.com/public/uploads/SA_HEM_cover_V06_copy_2_bd2ef4c55d.jpg?w=1920&q=75)

content.text_block:
Sound installation\
2021

This seed, or semilla, marks the beginning of something that grows in time, like an idea, like a movement. _Semilla_ is a small artefact, a sounding capsule containing a speaker and an mp3 player. Meant to be buried in the ground during a ritual, _Semilla_ is offered to the Earth as a symbolic act of resonance and active protection. From the underground, a subtle sound piece will emerge. This piece is composed with the resonant frequency of our planet. It is a resonant object that protects the place where it is buried as it produces noise and unwanted vibrations that render the ground unsoundable for geophones; extractive telluric sensors used by oil and gas companies to find new places for extraction.

content.image_caption: Nicole L'Huillier. Photo by Patricia Dominguez.

content.text_block: **Nicole L’Huillier** is a transdisciplinary artist from Santiago, Chile.

Through sound, vibrations, resonances, and multiple transductions, her work explores more-than-human performativity — from microscopic to cosmic scales; rituals of membranal and resonant architectures; as well as vibration and sound as construction materials for spaces, collectivity, identity, and agency. She has performed and exhibited widely at institutions including the Guggenheim Museum, Venice Architecture Biennale, Sónar +D, Ars Electronica, Institute of Contemporary Art Boston, SXSW, and Bienal de Artes Mediales Chile alongside many others. Currently based in Boston, L’Huillier completed a PhD in Media Arts & Sciences at MIT in 2022. She was recently selected for a residency at Transmediale and La Becque.

attributes.title: Walking In the Midst of It All

content.text_block: # EXHIBITION

Expanding from Sonic Acts' long term research focus on the implications of climate crisis, _one sun after another_ traces the inextricable nature of pollution and time. Unfolding in several places, the exhibition and its public programme of events engage with ecology across vast scales.

Taking its name from a poem in Etel Adnan’s powerful book _The Arab Apocalypse_ (1989), the biennial exhibition gestures toward the passing of time, but also carries traces of _Bhagavad Gita_, referenced by Robert Oppenheimer after witnessing the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ‘If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst at once into the sky, that would be like the splendour of the mighty one. I am become Death, The Shatterer of Worlds.’ Drawing upon this sublime, all-subsuming vision, one sun after another attends to slow, accumulative violence as it makes its imprint on futures yet to come. Touching on deep, real, geological time, the programme embraces nonlinearity, fluctuation and porousness, making space for leaks. Permeable to hope, the figure of the ever-dawning sun glows without burning, permeating warmth, fueling imagination and propagating life.

W139 open\

_Powerless Flight_ is accessible 24/7\

content.image_caption: _Gauge_, Danny Osborne, Patrick Thompson, Alexa Hatanaka, Sarah McNair-Landry, Eric McNair-Landry, Erik Boomer, and Raven Chacon. Photo by Erik Boomer.

content.text_block: Contemplating multiple incarnations of time, _one sun after another_ listens to an immersive aerial choir of bees, follows a microbe embedded within lithium traveling from a Chilean mine to a digital device, and plunges into deep time through lead-encased nuclear coconuts from the Bikini Atoll. Artistic research traces the lineages of exhaust produced by oil and other extractive economies, while in other places it speculates over Greenland’s mineral deposits, now made accessible by melting ice. In the Canadian Arctic, visual narratives on monumental ice walls come and go with tidal movements, soundtracked by a cacophony of environmental field recordings. Against the din, visitors are welcome to a joyful meditation about presence, sensing and bending time, before drifting downstream, where the exhibition stretches time even further. Diving under, performative and installative artworks explore toxic cycles of water and stretch inner time with hybrid instruments and sub-aquatic amplification.

## PUBLIC PROGRAMME

The exhibition is complimented by a public programme of a variety of events, emanating across W139 and Zone2Source in Amsterdam. Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.
→ [Find out more about the public programme](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/public-programme)

content.image_caption: Tomoko Sauvage. Photo by Leo Lopez.

content.text_block: **Tomoko Sauvage** is a musician and sound artist best known for her experiments with hybrid instruments combining water, ceramics, sub-aquatic amplification and electronics.

Her research is grounded in live-performance practices that embrace the unpredictable dynamics of materials. Incorporating ritualistic gestures, she playfully improvises with environments, using chance as a compositional method. Her performances and installations have been presented at RIBOCA, V&A Museum, Manifesta, Roskilde Festival, Sharjah Art Foundation, Centre Pompidou Metz and Nyege Nyege Festival, among others. Recorded in a water tank in Berlin, utilising self-invented ‘natural synthesisers’: porcelain and glass bowls, filled with liquid and amplified by hydrophones, her third solo album _Fischgeist_ was released in 2020. Sauvage lives and works in Paris.
[Website](https://o-o-o-o.org/)

Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

content.image_caption: Anthea Caddy performing _Long Throw_ at Sonic Acts Academy 2020, Stedelijk Museum. Photo by Pieter Kers.

content.text_block: Her practice explores the spatio-temporal aspects of sound and architecture, crafting audio works that manipulate and distort perceptions of time, space and experience. Caddy’s work focuses on the incorporation of acoustic, electro-acoustic and recorded space within performance, installation and concert presentation, often using amplified cello as her primary sound source. In her live performance she uses multi-channel configurations in low lighting or complete darkness. She has performed and exhibited at Issue Project Room, Wroclaw Museum of Contemporary Art, Borealis, and Maerz Musik. Caddy is a PhD candidate under media historian Douglas Kahn at UNSW Sydney, Australia. In 2020, Caddy performed _Long Throw_ as part of Sonic Acts Academy. Later that year, Caddy presented _Projection #3: The Wharf_ in Amsterdam’s NDSM, a commissioned piece by Sonic Acts, realised and built in close collaboration with media artist and engineer Miodrag Gladović.

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/antheacaddy)

content.image_caption: Tati au Miel. Phoro by Neva Wireko.

content.text_block: **Tati au Miel’s** interdisciplinary practice explores the liberatory potential of sound — creating evocative performances in relation to their own identity as a queer, gender fluid Haitian-Canadian.

Their work stretches across experimental sound, costume design, and textile experimentation. Through these speculative experimentations, Tati au Miel approaches the radical potential of storytelling tied to the legacies of black electronic music. Since their first EP _The Exorcism of Tania Daniel_ in 2019, Tati au Miel has produced mixes for major outlets including dublab, Rinse FM, NTS, Mutek, and has performed internationally. Their most recent album The _Fantastical World of Tati au Miel Vol. I_ was released in 2022.

[Bandcamp](https://tatiaumiel.bandcamp.com/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/tatiaumiel)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/tatiaumiel/)

content.image_caption: PLF. Photo by Florian Kindlinger.

content.text_block: **PFL** are an unorthodox band, brushing against the edge of post-punk industrialism, noise-pop and free-improvisation.

PLF consist of Kutin’s self-devised light-feedback noise machines, Lukas König’s exquisite percussion-electronics and fake rhythm section, and Elvin Brandhi’s feral and unpredictable vocalisations. They play fake logic without any regard for the listener and are not present on any social media platform. A dynamic tour de force, every PLF concert is fully improvised – rhythmic abysses, beguiling voices, and a heady array of synths emerging from the interplay of three musicians intent on seducing audiences as much as confronting them. In 2022 their debut album _EPDEMO_ was released on the British label Opal Tapes.

content.text_block: **Saranghwae** is a fluid art collective that engages in active exchanges between creators at the crossroads of art, science, and technology.

During 2022, all members of Saranghwae including **Sunjeong Hwang, Junsoo Kim, So Young Lee, Suhun Lee, Gyuchul Moon**, and **[Mint Park](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/mint-park)**, have been working together for the collaborative project _Being as Praxis_, seeking to free their practices from pre-existing systems, genres, or forms of audiovisual results. Taking place between Seoul and Amsterdam, Saranghwae wishes to rediscover techne with the local communities, not as a set of devices or strategies but as an innovative tool for understanding cosmo-technic diversity and inclusivity. 


[Website](http://www.saranghwae.com/)


[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/saranghwae.archive/)

content.text_block:
**Saranghwae** is a fluid arts collective actively engaged at the crossroads of art, science, and technology. Taking shape as an experimental mix of an exhibition, performance and artist talk, the group presents a three day Open Lab in which fermentation serves as a model and metaphor. From beverages to pickled food, fermentation has long been a part of our cooking histories. A delicate art, fermenting involves a wide range of variable elements – specific substances, temperature, humidity, light and time are all important factors. Interlocked in a series of chemical reactions, micro-organisms, glucose and air are compounded. During the lab, these intricate conditions and processes – the natural cycles of pollution and purification – will be reconceptualised to propose a non-anthropocentric definition of ‘fermentation’. Through this (re)imagining, Saranghwae aims to envision how planetary beings co-exist in symbiotic relationships with their ecosystems.

Unfolding in three sections: _What to be Fermented?_ _How to be Fermented?_ and _Fermented?_, the three-day _Fermenting Art Lab_ consists of a performance and an artist talk in which **Saranghwae** shares their group research work. 

On Saturday, the Open Lab features Fermentation Recipes. Taking both physical and virtual forms, the recipes contain daily routines and rituals that are practiced by Saranghwae members. Visitors are cordially invited to participate at six working stations where the fermentation recipe and substances – scribbles, digital materials and installation pieces – will be laid out. We encourage participants to slowly spend their time at the Open Lab, analysing what gets selected and what is disposed of. Pop-up events will further shed light on specific elements of the recipe.

content.image_caption: Anika Schwarzlose. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Anika Schwarzlose** is an artist, researcher and lecturer.

She received a BA from the Gerrit Rietveld Academy and an MFA from the Konsthögskolan i Malmö. Her practice often involves collaborative production cycles and focuses on the reproduction techniques, the function of archives, and the repurposing of images. Her work exam-ines lens-based recordings and media, specifically the influence of dispersion, adap-tation and composition of images on specific narratives. Presently, she investigates ideas on machine and mineral evolution, machines as technofossils, human attempts of making kin with minerals and metabolic connections between life and non-life.

[Website](http://www.anikaschwarzlose.com/)

content.image_caption: Brian D. McKenna. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Brian D. McKenna**’s practice deals with technological environments and propaganda concerning the tools we use and how we use them.

His work investigates how technological environments interact with our concepts of self and notions of authenticity. His collaborative and solo works have been presented internationally at venues across Europe. In 2020, McKenna released the film _Unearth: In Between States of Matter_ (2020) in collaboration with **Anika Schwarzlose** and **BJ Nilsen**. Besides working independently and collaboratively as an artist, McKenna also works as a part-time instructor and technology researcher at the Sandberg Institute, and as a PhD candidate at the University of Amsterdam.

[Website](http://www.recordingmedium.com)

content.image_caption: HC Gilje. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: Interdisciplinary artist **HC Gilje** has moved between installation, experimental video, live performance and set design since he graduated from the Academy of Fine Arts in Trondheim in 1999.

During his decade-long collaboration with Sonic Acts, HC Gilje has worked on the Dark Ecology project; has premiered and presented work including _Blink_ (2010), _Revolver_ (2013), _Rift_ (2017), and _Radiant Live_ (2019);  publishing work on his long-term project _Conversations with Spaces_ (2017). Gilje was a member of the video-impro trio 242.pilots and was visual motor of dance company Kreutzerkompani. He has screened his work internationally and continues to perform live — collaborating with **Maja Ratkje** and **Justin Bennett** and creating projections and set designs for theatre and dance.



[Website]( www.hcgilje.com)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/hc_gilje/?hl=fr)

During his decade-long collaboration with Sonic Acts, HC Gilje has worked on the Dark Ecology project; has premiered and presented work including _Blink_ (2010), _Revolver_ (2013), _Rift_ (2017), and _Radiant Live_ (2019);  publishing work on his long-term project _Conversations with Spaces_ (2017). Gilje was a member of the video-impro trio 242.pilots and was visual motor of dance company Kreutzerkompani. He has screened his work internationally and continues to perform live — collaborating with **Maja Ratkje** and **Justin Bennett** and creating projections and set designs for theatre and dance.



[Website]( www.hcgilje.com)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/hc_gilje/?hl=fr)

_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

content.image_caption: Maria Komarova. Photo by Antonín Brinda.

content.text_block: **Maria Komarova** is a Belarusian interdisciplinary artist working on the fields of sound, performance, scenography and installation.

Komarova’s spatial work fosters a sense of curiosity and attention in the everyday; repurposing and emphasising the sonic and visual potential of commonplace objects through her installations. In her performances, Komarova works with DIY electro-acoustic instruments and found objects, letting them temporarily inhabit the site and interact with each other. Currently based in Prague, Komarova is a co-founder of the theatre collective _PYL_, _Performensk Festival_ in Belarus, and a member of the _band kaine anung_.
[Website](https://mariakomarova.org/)

content.image_caption: Farida Amadou. Photo by Laurent Orseau.

content.text_block: **Farida Amadou** is a self taught bass player based in Liège, Belgium.

Amadou is a member of the duo **Nystagmus** with drummer Tom Malmendier, and the punk/noise band **Cocaine Piss**. Since 2018, Amadou has performed under duo projects with the drummer Steve Noble, featuring trio collaborations with musicians including Alex Ward, Chris Pitsiokos, Thurston Moore, Julien Desprez and Peter Brötzmann. 

In 2020 Farida Amadou was  part of the OORSTOF series project with Ken Vandermark and his band MARKER, and the following year began two collaborative projects with Floris Vanhoof and Pavel Tchikov. In 2021 Amadou collaborated with the guitarist Pavel Tchikov, releasing her most recent album _Mal De Terre_.

[Website](https://faridamadou.com/)

[Bandcamp](https://farida-amadou.bandcamp.com/music)

content.image_caption: Leila Bordreuil. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Leila Bordreuil** is a French cellist, composer and sound artist based in Brooklyn, New York.

She accesses concepts as diverse as noise, contemporary classical, free jazz, and experimental traditions and yet adheres to none of them. Her music mixes deep melancholia with harsh noise-walls at earth shattering levels. Her compositions frequently incorporate sound-spatialization by way of site-specific pieces and multichannel installations. Bordreuil is a 2021 Jerome Foundation Artist Fellow and an Artist in Residence at **INA GRM**. Her work has been showcased at notable venues including The Whitney Museum, MoMA PS1, Le Guess Who, Cafe Oto, Sound of Stockholm Festival, among many others. She is currently interested in neurological perception and our physiological relationship to sound and space.

[Website](https://www.leilabordreuil.com/)

[Bandcamp](https://leilabordreuil.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Mattias Puech. Photo by Nils Maisonneuve.

content.text_block: **Matthias Puech** is an electronic musician, programmer, researcher and teacher.

Through his work as a development scientist for INA GRM and assistant Professor in Computer Science, Puech nourishes a dual interest for natural phenomena, especially evolutionary biology, and the mathematical and computational concepts that let us understand our world. Interpreting ‘ambient’ and ‘noise’ in their original sense, Puech’s compositions seek to disturb the distinction between sound synthesis and field recording, highlighting the symbiotic relationship between the machine and its environment. Matthias Puech designs his own instruments using unique synthesis algorithms inspired by physics and biology, and collaborates with manufacturers of modular synthesisers who then market his creations. Puech has released four full-length physical albums, his most recent album _A Geography of Absence_, was released in 2021. He has notably played live at  Cafe OTO in London, 100ECS, Péripate, Rinse France in Paris, CKUT Radio in Montréal, and has been commissioned by Radio France & GRM for live performances internationally. 

[Website](https://mqtthiqs.github.io/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/mqtthiqs)

content.image_caption: Iannis Xenakis. Photo by M Daniel.

content.text_block: **Iannis Klearchou Xenakis** (1922 − 2001) was a Romanian-born Greek-French avant-garde composer, music theorist, architect, performance director and engineer.

A key figure in the development of electronic and computer music, Xenakis pioneered the use of mathematical models in composition, including applications of set theory, stochastic processes and game theory. Trained as an architect, Xenakis integrated music with architecture practices, designing music for pre-existing spaces, and designing spaces to be integrated with specific music compositions and performances.

Xenakis’s long and fruitful association with the Paris Instrumental Ensemble for Contemporary Music led to frequent performances and recordings of his works for chamber ensemble. He established the School of Mathematical and Automatic Music in 1966. Xenakis also designed what he called ‘polytopes’, high-art son-et-lumière installations that involved his lighting designs, his sets, his music, and his sound projection to create vivid multi-media experiences, in places from Canada to Iran to Greece. His 1958 work _Achorripsis for 21 instruments_, led Xenakis to formulate his minimal rules of composition — rules that were subsequently expanded in the program for _ST/10-1,080262_ made between 1956–62. In 1971 he published the influential text _Formalized Music: Thought and Mathematics in Composition_.

[Website](https://www.iannis-xenakis.org/en/) 

[Bandcamp](https://recollectiongrm.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Félicia Atkinson. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: For French electro-acoustic composer and visual artist **Félicia Atkinson**, human voices inhabit an ecology within and alongside many – in the conventional sense – unspoken things: landscapes, images, books, memories, and ideas.

Atkinson makes music that animates these other possible voices in conversation with her own, collaging field recording, MIDI instrumentation, and snippets of essayistic language together with frequent engagement with the work of visual artists, filmmakers, and novelists. She is the co-founder of Shelter Press, through which she has released both a novel and many recordings. She has performed at venues and festivals including INA GRM/Maison de la Radio and the Philharmonie, Issue Project Room, the Barbican Center, Le Guess Who, Atonal, Henie Onstad, Unsound, and Skanu Mesz. She has exhibited in museums, galleries, and biennials across the world.
[Website](https://feliciaatkinson.com/)

content.image_caption: Jessica Ekomane. Photo by Camille Blake.

content.text_block: **Jessica Ekomane** is a French-born electronic musician and sound artist based in Berlin.

Known for her installations and live shows, Ekomane’s quadraphonic performances intertwine psychoacoustics, rhythmic structures, and the interchange of noise and melody – her fluid and immersive sonic landscapes questioning the links between individual perception, collective dynamics, and the social-political roots of the listening experience. In 2019, Ekomane was one of six composers chosen to collaborate with Natascha Süder Happelman at the Venice Biennale. That same year, Ekomane released her first LP _Multivocal_ via Important Records. Her work has been presented in various institutions worldwide such as Berlin’s CTM festival, Ars Electronica, Dommune in Tokyo and Bemis Center for Contemporary Arts in Omaha.

[Website](https://www.jessicaekomane.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/jessicaekomane/?hl=de) 

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/jessica-ekomane)

content.image_caption: Bernard Parmegiani. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Bernard Parmegiani** (1927 − 2013) was a French composer best known for his electronic acousmatic music.

Parmegiani's most famous work includes _Capture éphémère_ in 1967 and an interpretation of Dante Alighieri’s Divine Comedy, _L'Enfer_ in 1972, a collaboration with the composer François Bayle. Following four years of acting study at the prestigious Lecoq & Decroux school, Parmegiani joined GRM in 1959 as a postgraduate. His first major work, Violostries was composed in 1962 and directed by Jacques-Albert Cartier.

During this nascent period Parmegiani composed for numerous film directors and began to branch out into the  field of video-art after a journey across the United States. He directed three musical videos when he returned: _L’Œil écoute_ (1973), _Jeux d’artifices_ (1979) for the research department of ORTF, and L’Écran transparent (1973) in Köln during his residency at West Deutscher Rundfunk. His interests also expanded to live performance: in the seventies he interacted with jazz artists for improv sessions with french jazz fellows and went to London to perform live with The Third Ear Band.  Parmegiani’s music has won countless awards, among them prizes from the Académie du Disque Français in 1979, SACEM in 1981, Les Victoires de la Musique in 1990, and the Prix Magister at the Concours International de Bourges in 1991. In 1993 he was awarded the Golden Nica Award at Prix Ars Electronica for the composition _Entre-temps_.


[Website](https://bernard-parmegiani.fr/en/itineraire/biographie/)

[Bandcamp](https://recollectiongrm.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Nicole L'Huillier. Photo by Patricia Dominguez.

content.text_block: **Nicole L’Huillier** is a transdisciplinary artist from Santiago, Chile.

Through sound, vibrations, resonances, and multiple transductions, her work explores more-than-human performativity — from microscopic to cosmic scales; rituals of membranal and resonant architectures; as well as vibration and sound as construction materials for spaces, collectivity, identity, and agency. She has performed and exhibited widely at institutions including the Guggenheim Museum, Venice Architecture Biennale, Sónar +D, Ars Electronica, Institute of Contemporary Art Boston, SXSW, and Bienal de Artes Mediales Chile alongside many others. Currently based in Boston, L’Huillier completed a PhD in Media Arts & Sciences at MIT in 2022. She was recently selected for a residency at Transmediale and La Becque.

[Website](https://nicolelhuillier.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/nico_lh/)

content.image_caption: Anthea Caddy performing _Long Throw_ at Sonic Acts Academy 2020, Stedelijk Museum. Photo by Pieter Kers.

content.text_block: Her practice explores the spatio-temporal aspects of sound and architecture, crafting audio works that manipulate and distort perceptions of time, space and experience. Caddy’s work focuses on the incorporation of acoustic, electro-acoustic and recorded space within performance, installation and concert presentation, often using amplified cello as her primary sound source. In her live performance she uses multi-channel configurations in low lighting or complete darkness. She has performed and exhibited at Issue Project Room, Wroclaw Museum of Contemporary Art, Borealis, and Maerz Musik. Caddy is a PhD candidate under media historian Douglas Kahn at UNSW Sydney, Australia. In 2020, Caddy performed _Long Throw_ as part of Sonic Acts Academy. Later that year, Caddy presented _Projection #3: The Wharf_ in Amsterdam’s NDSM, a commissioned piece by Sonic Acts, realised and built in close collaboration with media artist and engineer Miodrag Gladović.

[Website](https://antheacaddy.net/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/antheacaddy)

attributes.title: Silence x Sonic Acts concert: Anthea Caddy

content.text_block: # EXHIBITION

Expanding from Sonic Acts' long term research focus on the implications of climate crisis, _one sun after another_ traces the inextricable nature of pollution and time. Unfolding in several places, the exhibition and its public programme of events engage with ecology across vast scales.

Taking its name from a poem in Etel Adnan’s powerful book _The Arab Apocalypse_ (1989), the biennial exhibition gestures toward the passing of time, but also carries traces of _Bhagavad Gita_, referenced by Robert Oppenheimer after witnessing the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ‘If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst at once into the sky, that would be like the splendour of the mighty one. I am become Death, The Shatterer of Worlds.’ Drawing upon this sublime, all-subsuming vision, one sun after another attends to slow, accumulative violence as it makes its imprint on futures yet to come. Touching on deep, real, geological time, the programme embraces nonlinearity, fluctuation and porousness, making space for leaks. Permeable to hope, the figure of the ever-dawning sun glows without burning, permeating warmth, fueling imagination and propagating life.

content.image_caption: _Gauge_, Danny Osborne, Patrick Thompson, Alexa Hatanaka, Sarah McNair-Landry, Eric McNair-Landry, Erik Boomer, and Raven Chacon. Photo by Erik Boomer.

content.text_block: Contemplating multiple incarnations of time, _one sun after another_ listens to an immersive aerial choir of bees, follows a microbe embedded within lithium traveling from a Chilean mine to a digital device, and plunges into deep time through lead-encased nuclear coconuts from the Bikini Atoll. Artistic research traces the lineages of exhaust produced by oil and other extractive economies, while in other places it speculates over Greenland’s mineral deposits, now made accessible by melting ice. In the Canadian Arctic, visual narratives on monumental ice walls come and go with tidal movements, soundtracked by a cacophony of environmental field recordings. Against the din, visitors are welcome to a joyful meditation about presence, sensing and bending time, before drifting downstream, where the exhibition stretches time even further. Diving under, performative and installative artworks explore toxic cycles of water and stretch inner time with hybrid instruments and sub-aquatic amplification.

## PUBLIC PROGRAMME

The exhibition is complimented by a public programme of a variety of events, emanating across W139 and Zone2Source in Amsterdam. Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.
→ [Find out more about the public programme](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/public-programme)

content.image_caption: Tomoko Sauvage. Photo by Leo Lopez.

content.text_block: **Tomoko Sauvage** is a musician and sound artist best known for her experiments with hybrid instruments combining water, ceramics, sub-aquatic amplification and electronics.

Her research is grounded in live-performance practices that embrace the unpredictable dynamics of materials. Incorporating ritualistic gestures, she playfully improvises with environments, using chance as a compositional method. Her performances and installations have been presented at RIBOCA, V&A Museum, Manifesta, Roskilde Festival, Sharjah Art Foundation, Centre Pompidou Metz and Nyege Nyege Festival, among others. Recorded in a water tank in Berlin, utilising self-invented ‘natural synthesisers’: porcelain and glass bowls, filled with liquid and amplified by hydrophones, her third solo album _Fischgeist_ was released in 2020. Sauvage lives and works in Paris.
[Website](https://o-o-o-o.org/)

content.text_block:
Welcome to [l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/l-a-g)!

Soundcamp collective and radio artist Kate Donovan host an open radio space and workshop-hub at the Homebase in Het HEM, with microphone and transistor building, dusk listening and fieldwalks, tuning to live sounds of the site.

**Tune into the 58 hour-long broadcast online via the play button at the top of sonicacts.com from Friday 7 October to Sunday 9 October.** The transmission is aired from the Homebase situated in the central hall of Het HEM, the Huiskamer and at various movable listening points dispersed around the Hembrug site.

_l a g_ occurs as an unpredictable ghost in the live archive of streams, as sounds move and appear out of place. lt brings stutters, drops or echoes that can put us into close contact with both what just occured and is about to.

# Contribute your own! Join in the stream below:

content.url: <iframe id="irc" height="500px" width="756px" frameborder="0" border="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="default" src="https://irc.soundtent.org/?&theme=soundcamp_irc_v1_white#acousticommons"></iframe>

content.text_block: The Soundcamp programme has been devised and curated specially for the Sonic Acts Biennial.

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block: **Soundcamp** is an arts cooperative based in London, Crete and The Hague, working on transmission ecologies ranging from DIY broadcasting devices to public sound and radio projects.

As part of the Acoustic Commons network, Soundcamp coordinates the long-form radio broadcast Reveil, in addition to an annual series of sound and ecology events on Dawn Chorus. In 2020, Soundcamp initiated the Creative Europe small cooperation project: _Acoustic Commons_, in partnership with arts organisations in Europe and Japan. Recent projects include _As if radio.._ at COP26 Glasgow, _Meet Me On The Radio_, _Biosphere Open Microphones_, and the portable audio system _PITCH_. With expertise in environmental sound, transmission art and participatory technologies, Soundcamp regularly organises workshops and exchanges as part of a socially engaged practice.
[Website](https://soundtent.org/soundcamp_about.html)

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.image_caption: Kate Donovan. Photo by Bryan Zimmerman.

content.text_block: **Kate Donovan** is a Berlin-based artist, researcher and facilitator working with radio, listening and the more-than-human.

In her collaborative radio practice, Donovan is a member of CoLaboRadio, Datscha Radio, and the international feminist group Shortwave Collective. She has made work for radio stations, art organisations and festivals across the world, and her writing appears in online and print publications, including _Versorgerin_, _Explore Dance_, _Fusion_, and _Seismograf_. Donovan is a member of the research group _SENSING: the Knowledge of Sensitive Media_ and is co-founder of the artistic research project _Radio Otherwise_. 

[Website](mattersoftransmission.net)

[Radio Otherwise](www.radiootherwise.net)

content.image_caption: Samson Young, _Nocturne _ at Kunsthaus Bregenz. Photo by Miro Kuzmanovic.

content.text_block: Multi-disciplinary artist **Samson Young** works in sound, performance, video, and installation.

Young was Hong Kong Sinfonietta’s Artist Associate from 2008 to 2009 and – following study in Sydney and Hong Kong – received his PhD in Music Composition from Princeton University in 2013. His compositions, drawings, installations, radio broadcasts, and performances touch upon topics such as identity, military conflict, migration, and political frontiers past and present. In 2015, Young was the inaugural recipient of the BMW Art Journey Award and in 2017, he represented Hong Kong at the 57th Venice Biennale. Alongside a wide variety of Biennials and group exhibitions, including shows at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Shanghai Biennale, Linz’s Ars Electronica, and Documenta; Young’s solo exhibitions include, to mention a few, the De Appel, Kunsthalle Düsseldorf, Talbot Rice Gallery, Chicago’s SMART Museum, and the M+ Pavilion in Hong Kong. In 2020, he was awarded the inaugural Uli Sigg Prize.
[Website](https://www.thismusicisfalse.com/)

_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

→ [Read through the Inner Ear(th) programme here](https://pdfhost.io/v/iUue4sUGj_Inner_Earth_Programme) (PDF)

→ [View the Het HEM floorplan here](https://cms.sonicacts.com/public/uploads/SA_HEM_cover_V06_copy_2_bd2ef4c55d.jpg?w=1920&q=75)

content.image_caption: Ailbhe Nic Oireachtaigh. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Ailbhe Nic Oireactaigh** is an Irish violist and composer living in Glasgow.

Following a classical training, Nic Oireactaigh was drawn to improvisation and she enrolled in studies for jazz performance. Following graduation, her growing interest in Baroque traditions led to explorations in the tonal possibilities of gut strings; findings she used in both amplified and acoustic contexts. These improvised, traditional and early music influences can be heard on her solo recordings _Oreing_ (2017) and _The Rounds_ (2021); her touring work with experimental bands Woven Skull, Cian Nugent & the Cosmos and musicians including Josephine Foster and Circuit des Yeux, alongside her compositions for theatre and orchestra. In Glasgow, she has performed and collaborated with a wide variety of contemporary bands, musicians, and composers.

[Website](https://www.ailbhenicoireachtaigh.com/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/ailbhenicoireachtaigh)

content.image_caption: Hüma Utku. Photo by Gözde Güngör.

content.text_block: Hailing from Istanbul, Berlin-based composer and sound artist **Hüma Utku** explores the possibilities of sound textures and rhythm to evoke a sense of ancient within advanced electronic music.

Following her releases _Şeb-i Yelda_ (2018) and _Gnosis_ (2019); Utku released her sophomore album _The Psychologist_ in 2022. Already recognised for her unique approach to sonic storytelling, _The Psychologist_ has been hailed as Utku's most ambitious, authentic and complex work yet. Intertwining her background as a graduate of psychology and her current practice as a conceptual music composer, the album blurs dreams, reality, and hyperreality; a surreal stage upon which Utku's interrogates the human condition. Since 2016 she has presented her work in institutions such as Atonal Berlin, CTM Festival, HKW, Today's Art, Donaufestival among others. In 2021 Utku was selected as a SHAPE platform artist.

[Bandcamp](https://humautku.bandcamp.com/album/the-psychologist)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/huma.utku/?hl=de) 

[Website](https://humautku.com/)

content.text_block: **Saranghwae** is a fluid art collective that engages in active exchanges between creators at the crossroads of art, science, and technology.

During 2022, all members of Saranghwae including **Sunjeong Hwang, Junsoo Kim, So Young Lee, Suhun Lee, Gyuchul Moon**, and **[Mint Park](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/mint-park)**, have been working together for the collaborative project _Being as Praxis_, seeking to free their practices from pre-existing systems, genres, or forms of audiovisual results. Taking place between Seoul and Amsterdam, Saranghwae wishes to rediscover techne with the local communities, not as a set of devices or strategies but as an innovative tool for understanding cosmo-technic diversity and inclusivity. 


[Website](http://www.saranghwae.com/)


[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/saranghwae.archive/)

content.image_caption: Maria Komarova. Photo by Antonín Brinda.

content.text_block: **Maria Komarova** is a Belarusian interdisciplinary artist working on the fields of sound, performance, scenography and installation.

Komarova’s spatial work fosters a sense of curiosity and attention in the everyday; repurposing and emphasising the sonic and visual potential of commonplace objects through her installations. In her performances, Komarova works with DIY electro-acoustic instruments and found objects, letting them temporarily inhabit the site and interact with each other. Currently based in Prague, Komarova is a co-founder of the theatre collective _PYL_, _Performensk Festival_ in Belarus, and a member of the _band kaine anung_.
[Website](https://mariakomarova.org/)

content.image_caption: Music Research Strategies. Photo by Mark Datter.

content.text_block: **Marshall Trammell** is an experimental archivist, percussionist, conductor, and composer, performing as **Music Research Strategies**.

His aesthetics and activism are centred in social change interventions and generate new local and global ecologies that embrace improvisation as a collective, movement-building tool in the creation of post-capitalist imaginaries. Working with Palestinian experimental musician Dirar Kalash, Trammell’s new collaborative project _Black Fight Formations_ (BFF) presents itself as a mode of cultural weaponry, referencing analyses by former Black Panther member and Black Liberation Army soldier Russell ‘Maroon’ Shoatz. Past iterations of BFF have included Guggenheim recipient Lisa E. Harris, Jawwaad Taylor, Shavon Moore, Ada Pinkston, Luke Stewart, Jamal Moore, Chinyere E. Oteh, Jemma DeCristo, Mogauwane Mohele, and members of AfroVan Connect.

[Bandcamp](https://bandcamp.com/tag/marshall-trammell)

[Website](https://www.musicresearchstrategies.info/)

content.image_caption: Dirar Kalash by Cristina Marx.

content.text_block: **Dirar Kalash** is a musician and sound artist whose work spans a wide range of musical and sonic practices within a variety of instrumental, compositional and improvisational contexts.

Kalash also extends his practice into interdisciplinary theoretical research. He has produced several solo and collaborative musical albums and is active as touring musician, in addition to that he also created several sound installations, live audio-visual performances, and photography projects. In 2020, Kalash released his most recent album, _Of Quietude on Discus_ records.
[Website](https://www.dirarkalash.info/)

content.image_caption: Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **pantea** is an interdisciplinary artist from Iran engaging with narratives of ecological and more-than-human connection.

Her work has incorporated performance, creative nonfiction, film, photography, and music. More recently, pantea is focused on developing a socially engaged practice by exploring possibilities brought about by sound and listening. She is passionate about the environment, plants, and wetlands. pantea is one half of the design group Studio Informal and a member of Khamoosh, an artistic research group dedicated to preserving and archiving Iranian sonic heritage. Her work on the plant Sundew has been published in Plumwood Mountain Journal, with other works performed and exhibited internationally across the Netherlands, Germany, Belgium, India, Turkey, and Scotland. More recently, pantea is a 2021 Sonic Acts OVEREXPOSED resident and in 2022 presented the installation _Fragile Fragments_ at CTM Festival in collaboration with Berlin-based duo u-matic & telematique.

[Website](https://pantearm.github.io/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/pantearm/)

content.image_caption: u-matic & telematique. Photo courtesy of the Artists.

content.text_block: Through the art duo **u-matic & telematique**, **Ute Härting** and **Sven Gareis** work with time-based and interactive media.

Their live performances, video installations, and workshops incorporate interactive stage sets, VR, and large-scale projections onto public buildings. Through these innovative projects, the duo seeks to expand the means through which to visualise the sound of the city, both within the streets of their home town Berlin, and within wider engagement with public space. Conceptually, u-matic & telematique’s work navigates the intangible by creatively engaging with various temporal frameworks and processes of digital creation. Through a playful engagement with blur, erosion, loops, stroboscopes and noise, the duo navigates the ephemerality of perception and presence.

[Website u-matic](http://www.u-matic.de/)

[Website telematique](http://www.telematique.de/de/)
