content.image_caption: Olivia Block. Photo by Walter Wlodarczyk.

content.text_block: **Olivia Block** is a media artist and composer.

For nearly thirty years, Block has created multi-channel, multi-speaker concerts, sound installations, recordings and scores for chamber music and orchestra. Block’s sound pieces include field recordings, electronic sounds, and musical instruments, varying in style, and yet maintaining a distinctive emotional sensibility. Her recordings are published on labels including Another Timbre, Erstwhile, Glistening Examples, NNA Tapes, Room40, Sedimental, and Touch. Block is an instructor in the Sound Department at The School of the Art Institute, and at Northwestern University in the Sound Arts and Industries program. Her new album,_ Innocent Passage in the Territorial Sea_ was released in 2021.

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/oliviablocksound/)

[Website](https://www.oliviablock.net/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/olivia-block)

[Bandcamp](https://oliviablock.bandcamp.com/music)

content.image_caption: Nina Garcia. Photo by Greg Clement.

content.text_block: The music of **Nina Garcia** experiments in the halfway place between improvisation and noise.

In her practice, devices are reduced to the minimum: a guitar, a pedal, an amplifier — undecorated yet essential tools in carving out sound from chaos. In the solo project _Mariachi_, Garcia pays close attention to the gestures, complexities, and history of her guitar: its resonances, its limits, its extensions, and its impurities. These details appear across Garcia’s soundscapes, physical irregularities accentuated through her use of feedback, crackling, short circuit, impact, speaks and unexpected notes. During this process, moments of unexpected perfection rise from the depths of Garcia’s crafted cacophony — expertly placed chords threading through the tumult. In this duality between harmony and chaos sits Garcia, more like a duet than a solo, a stunning blend of technical mastery and total freedom.

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/user-897060374)

[Website](https://www.parabailarlabamba.fr/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/nina.garcia.mariachi/?hl=de)

content.image_caption: Jaap Vink. Photo by Floris van Manen.

content.text_block: **Jaap Vink** is a Dutch engineer and electronic musician best known for his spatial recordings and electro-acoustic compositions.

He attended courses in electroacoustics at Delft University of Technology and installed a pedagogical studio for electronic music in 1961 at the Gaudeamus Foundation in Bilthoven with the help of the Nederlandse Radio Unie (NRU). Together with Gottfried Michael Koenig, Jaap Vink worked at the CEM studio for electronic music in Bilthoven during the 1960s, combining the electronic equipment, assembling special electronics, performing maintenance and assisting composers. Vink was a staff member at the Institute of Sonology as a teacher in analogue studio techniques from 1967 until his retirement in 1993. In this role Vink assisted visiting and resident composers in sound composition and production techniques; meanwhile composing and developing his own electronic analog pieces including 2-track stereo and 4-track spatial recordings. 

Although his music was entirely produced with purely electronic sound material, its textures resemble the richness of orchestral sounds, or large natural sound-complexes, as a result of recursive processes. The density of this sound material increases and decreases by careful control of feedback networks, with configurations of analogue tape recorder delay lines, filters, and modulators.

[Bandcamp](https://recollectiongrm.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Lucy Railton. Photo by Camille Blake.

content.text_block: Berlin and London-based cellist **Lucy Railton** has been an active performer, music producer and composer for over a decade, releasing albums on Modern Love, Editions Mego — GRM Portraits, PAN with Peter Zinovieff, and Takuroku.

Having emerged from a long-term engagement with classical and contemporary music, her practice exists between modern instrumentalism, electroacoustic composition, improvisation and expressive musique concrète. Over the years Railton has engaged with a range of interdisciplinary collaborations, and tours internationally as a solo performer or in collaboration with musicians and artists from a range of disciplines, most recently Rebecca Salvadori, Farida Amadou, Catherine Lamb, Kali Malone, Khyam Allami, Kit Downes and Stephen O’Malley. In 2016, Railton presented _Unknown_ in collaboration with Russell Haswell, a Sonic Acts commissioned work drawing on the pair’s time in the industrial and natural surroundings of the Barents Region.

[Website](https://lucyrailton.com/)

[Bandcamp](https://lucyrailton.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Aho Ssan. Photo by Marvin Jouglineu.

content.text_block: **Aho Ssan** is the artist name of Paris based musician and composer Niamké Désiré.

Following his studies in Graphic Design and Cinema, he began to compose electronic music and create his own digital instruments. Not long after, Aho Ssan was awarded the Foundation France Television Prize for his soundtrack to the film _Ingha Mago_ (2015), and subsequently embarked on several projects for Paris’ IRCAM/GRM. His debut LP _Simulacrum_ was released in 2020 through Subtext Recordings. Juxtaposing the theories of Jean Baudrillard alongside his own memories, _Simulacrum_ navigates its way through society’s presentation of inclusivity and equality; positioning these narratives against the lived experience of growing up black in France. Aho Ssan’s most recent work, _Thirteen Minute Cave_, was released in 2021.

[Instagram ](https://www.instagram.com/aho_ssan/?hl=de)


[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/ahossan)


[Bandcamp](https://ahossan.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Michèle Bokanowski. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Michèle Bokanowski** is a French composer most well known for her innovative ten-part score to the 1982 film _L’Ange_.

Educated in classical music, Bokanowski continued her studies in composition in Paris with Michel Puig and in electronic music in 1970 at the Service de la recherche de l’ORTF (ORTF) directed by Pierre Schaeffer. During this period, Bokanowski also studied computer music at the Faculté de Vincennes and electronic music with Eliane Radigue.

After completing her studies, Bokanowski worked as a composer, regularly composing in collaborating with Patrick Bokanowski for film, Catheringe Dasté for theatre works, and choreographers Hideyuki Yano, Marceline Lartigue and Bernardo Montet for dance. As a composer of electro-acoustic music she skillfully employs looping, reinjection, and  montage ‘scripting’. Bokanowski’s music is characterised by the use of concrete sounds and repetitive mechanisms in which expressivity is paramount. 

[Bandcamp](https://recollectiongrm.bandcamp.com/)

_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

→ [Read through the Inner Ear(th) programme here](https://pdfhost.io/v/iUue4sUGj_Inner_Earth_Programme) (PDF)

→ [View the Het HEM floorplan here](https://cms.sonicacts.com/public/uploads/SA_HEM_cover_V06_copy_2_bd2ef4c55d.jpg?w=1920&q=75)

l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block:
Welcome to [l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/l-a-g)!

Soundcamp collective and radio artist Kate Donovan host an open radio space and workshop-hub at the Homebase in Het HEM, with microphone and transistor building, dusk listening and fieldwalks, tuning to live sounds of the site.

**Tune into the 58 hour-long broadcast online via the play button at the top of sonicacts.com from Friday 7 October to Sunday 9 October.** The transmission is aired from the Homebase situated in the central hall of Het HEM, the Huiskamer and at various movable listening points dispersed around the Hembrug site.

_l a g_ occurs as an unpredictable ghost in the live archive of streams, as sounds move and appear out of place. lt brings stutters, drops or echoes that can put us into close contact with both what just occured and is about to.

# Contribute your own! Join in the stream below:

content.image_caption: Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **pantea** is an interdisciplinary artist from Iran engaging with narratives of ecological and more-than-human connection.

Her work has incorporated performance, creative nonfiction, film, photography, and music. More recently, pantea is focused on developing a socially engaged practice by exploring possibilities brought about by sound and listening. She is passionate about the environment, plants, and wetlands. pantea is one half of the design group Studio Informal and a member of Khamoosh, an artistic research group dedicated to preserving and archiving Iranian sonic heritage. Her work on the plant Sundew has been published in Plumwood Mountain Journal, with other works performed and exhibited internationally across the Netherlands, Germany, Belgium, India, Turkey, and Scotland. More recently, pantea is a 2021 Sonic Acts OVEREXPOSED resident and in 2022 presented the installation _Fragile Fragments_ at CTM Festival in collaboration with Berlin-based duo u-matic & telematique.

[Website](https://pantearm.github.io/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/pantearm/)

content.text_block:
**Saranghwae** is a fluid arts collective actively engaged at the crossroads of art, science, and technology. Taking shape as an experimental mix of an exhibition, performance and artist talk, the group presents a three day Open Lab in which fermentation serves as a model and metaphor. From beverages to pickled food, fermentation has long been a part of our cooking histories. A delicate art, fermenting involves a wide range of variable elements – specific substances, temperature, humidity, light and time are all important factors. Interlocked in a series of chemical reactions, micro-organisms, glucose and air are compounded. During the lab, these intricate conditions and processes – the natural cycles of pollution and purification – will be reconceptualised to propose a non-anthropocentric definition of ‘fermentation’. Through this (re)imagining, Saranghwae aims to envision how planetary beings co-exist in symbiotic relationships with their ecosystems.

Unfolding in three sections: _What to be Fermented?_ _How to be Fermented?_ and _Fermented?_, the three-day _Fermenting Art Lab_ consists of a performance and an artist talk in which **Saranghwae** shares their group research work. 

On Saturday, the Open Lab features Fermentation Recipes. Taking both physical and virtual forms, the recipes contain daily routines and rituals that are practiced by Saranghwae members. Visitors are cordially invited to participate at six working stations where the fermentation recipe and substances – scribbles, digital materials and installation pieces – will be laid out. We encourage participants to slowly spend their time at the Open Lab, analysing what gets selected and what is disposed of. Pop-up events will further shed light on specific elements of the recipe.

content.image_caption: Sarangwhae. Photo courtesy of the Artists.

content.text_block: **Saranghwae** is a fluid art collective that engages in active exchanges between creators at the crossroads of art, science, and technology.

During 2022, all members of Saranghwae including **Sunjeong Hwang, Junsoo Kim, So Young Lee, Suhun Lee, Gyuchul Moon**, and **[Mint Park](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/mint-park)**, have been working together for the collaborative project _Being as Praxis_, seeking to free their practices from pre-existing systems, genres, or forms of audiovisual results. Taking place between Seoul and Amsterdam, Saranghwae wishes to rediscover techne with the local communities, not as a set of devices or strategies but as an innovative tool for understanding cosmo-technic diversity and inclusivity. 


[Website](http://www.saranghwae.com/)


[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/saranghwae.archive/)

content.image_caption: Dania. Photo by Cecilia Diaz Betz.

content.text_block: An architect of textured, neo-ambient soundscapes, the music of **Dania Shihab** explores both sound and identity, focusing on how the latter has fractured in a post-colonial world.

Born in Baghdad, raised in Tasmania and now based in Barcelona, she moves between cultures and continents, her amorphous creative vision directly tied to her transient existence. The founder of experimental outpost Paralaxe Editions, Dania divides her time between Spain and the remote corners of Australia, where she works as an emergency doctor. Her musical practice, however, is preoccupied with harmonics and tonality, weaving together manipulated vocal fragments, processed field recordings and meditative atmospheres. In August 2022, her album _Voz_ was released on the label Geographic North.
[Bandcamp](https://daniavoz.bandcamp.com/releases)

content.image_caption: Tarek Atoui. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Tarek Atoui** is a contemporary artist born in Beirut and now living in Paris.

Atoui’s work investigates how sound can be perceived as a trans-sensory experience, how sound acts as a catalyst for human interaction, and how it relates to social, historical, and spatial parameters. His technical research is often extensively anthropological, ethnological and musicological — resulting in the creation of instruments, listening rooms, performances, and workshops. Atoui has presented his work internationally at the Sharjah Biennial, Documenta 13 in Kassel, the 8th Berlin Biennial, Tate Modern, CCA NTU in Singapore, Garage Moscow, the 58th International Art Exhibition of la Biennale di Venezia, among many others. He was appointed co-artistic director of STEIM studios in 2007, and of the Bergen Assembly, a triennial for contemporary art in Norway in 2016. In 2020, Tarek Atoui was the recipient of the Suzanne Deal Booth / FLAG Art Foundation Prize.

content.image_caption: Arnaud Rivière. Photo by Raphaelle Bloch.

content.text_block: Since the late 90s, sound artist **Arnaud Rivière** has positioned himself as an unabashed feedbackophile, his practice utilising rudimentary electroacoustic devices built around a repaired turntable, a prepared-mixer and other electronics necessitating constant and curious manipulation.

Based near Paris, Rivière is constantly active within the city’s cultural and sonic landscape: regularly performing at concerts and outdoor gatherings; organising workshops; and making recordings, sound installations, and videos. Through these practices, he lives a life defined by an enthusiastic need for the communal and social potentialities of sound.

[Website](http://http.http.http.http.free.fr/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/httphttphttphttp)

content.image_caption: Beatriz Ferreyra. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: Beatriz Ferreyra is an Argentinian composer and educator known for her musique concrète compositions.

Ferreyra was born in Cordoba, Argentina, and studied piano with Celia Bronstein in Buenos Aires. She continued her study of music with Nadia Boulanger and Edgardo Cantón in Paris, and worked with Earle Brown and György Ligeti in Germany. Ferreyra worked at GRM from 1963 to 1970, where she participated in the production of recordings for Pierre Schaeffer’s 1967 work _Solfège de l’Objet Sonore_. During GRM training periods, Ferreyra worked as a teacher and educator, giving lectures and courses at the Conservatoire National de Musique de Paris. Since 1970, she has worked as an independent composer, alongside conducting instrumental research in collaboration with Bernard Baschet on his _Structures Sonores_ (1970). In 1975, she became member of Collège des Compositeurs created by the GMEB. In 1976, Ferreyra worked at Dartmouth College in Hanover in the United States, before training and studying in music therapy. More recently, she curated a series of musique concrète concerts at Centre d'Études et de Recherche Pierre Schaeffer in Montbelliard, France in 1998. Ferreyra has released several albums to critical acclaim and has composed for ballet, theatre and concert. Ferreyre continues to perform live and regularly conducts workshops in acoustic composition.

[Website](https://beatrizferreyra.odavia.com/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/beatriz-ferreyra)

content.image_caption: Jules Négrier. Photo by Didier Allard.

content.text_block: **Jules Négrier** worked at the french national radio on spatial audio projects before joining the GRM in 2018 as a programming assistant.

He holds an MA in acousmatic music and sound art from the University of Marne La Vallée, France. Négrier composes electroacoustic music and performs live diffusions of these works internationally.

[Website](https://www.acousmonium.info/jules-negrier)

content.image_caption: Ben Bertand. Photo by Julie Calbert.

content.text_block: **Ben Bertrand** is a Belgian bass clarinettist and composer.

Through a blend of classical instruments and countless machines, Bertrand weaves intricate live sets characterised by a hypnotic web of sounds, using a vibrant selection of effects to create unusual soundscapes that confuse perception – sounding both at once electronic and acoustic. Alongside his release of records including _Era/Area_ (2017), _NGC 1999_ (2018), and _Manes_ (2020), Bertrand has performed at events including Meakusma Festival, Ancienne Belgique, Le Lieu Unique, BRDCST Festival, Schiev Festival, Le Guess Who?, World Minimal Music Festival and Rewire. His most recent album _Dokkaebi_, was released by Les Ateliers Claus in 2021.

[Bandcamp](https://benbertrand.bandcamp.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/ben.bertrand.music/?hl=de)

content.image_caption: François Bayle. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **François Bayle** is a French electronic and musique concrète composer.

Following study in the 1950s alongside figures like **Olivier Messiaen, Pierre Schaeffer** and **Karlheinz Stockhausen**, in 1960 Bayle joined the Office de Radiodiffusion Télévision Française (ORTF), recently established by Pierre Schaeffer. Six years later Schaeffer placed Bayle in charge of the GRM. 

From then on Bayle remained active as a composer, an administrator and a music theorist at the centre of GRM proceedings. During this period he organised concerts, radio broadcasts, seminars and events celebrating individual composers, supported technological developments, and was behind major innovations, such as the INA-GRM label and the world-renowned Acousmonium. In 1992, Bayle also founded the Acousmathèque with the GRM library, gathering more than 2000 works composed since 1948. After leaving GRM in 1997, Bayle founded his own audio-numerical and multiphonic studio, the studio _Magison_, where he has devoted himself to research, writing and composition. In the world of electronic art music, Bayle is regarded as one of the most distinguished composers; his influence is widespread (particularly in France, Europe and French-speaking Canada) and his music has earned some of the most prestigious musical prizes, international awards, and honorary doctorates, most notably a Commandeur dans l'ordre des Arts et des Lettres, Grand Prix des compositeurs SACEM in 1978, the Prix Ars Electronica in 1989 and the Grand Prix de la Fondation Del Duca in 2007. 

[Bandcamp](https://francoisbayle.bandcamp.com/)
# PUBLIC PROGRAMME
The public programme of _one sun after another_ emanates across **W139** and **Zone2Source** in Amsterdam, with a variety of events, workshops and sessions occurring throughout the city.

Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.

attributes.title: Enrico Malatesta & Tomoko Sauvage Sound Walk
Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Félix Blume, photo by Johan Legraie.

content.text_block: In the audiovisual work and installations of sound artist and engineer **Félix Blume**, listening emerges as a core tool, a means to encourage the awareness of the imperceptible, and as an act of encounter with others.

Blume’s artistic practice is often collaborative, working with communities and using public space as a context within which to explore and present work. Intrigued by myths and their contemporary reinterpretations, he hones in on human dialogues with both inhabited natural and urban environments, tuning into what voices can say beyond words. Blume's pieces have been broadcasted by radio stations around the world. A recipient of the Paysage Sonore Prize for the video piece _Curupira, Creature of the Wood_ (2018) Blume was also presented with the Pierre Schaeffer prize for _Los Gritos de México_ (2015) at the Phonurgia Nova Awards. He has participated in festivals and exhibitions including LOOP Barcelona, Ex Teresa, Arts Santa Monica, CTM, Thailand Biennale, and the International Film Festival Rotterdam.  In April 2022, he participated in Sonic Acts's Night Air programme _Shifting Sands_, to explore the ecological impacts of sand excavation and consumption, which are marred by displacement and continuous expansion. Blume resides between France, Mexico, and Brazil.

[Website](https://felixblume.com/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/felixblume)

content.image_caption: Maryam Monalisa Gharavi at Sonic Acts Festival 2017, 24 February. Photo by Pieter Kers.

content.text_block: **Maryam Monalisa Gharavi** is an artist, poet, and theorist whose work deals with the paradoxes of our interactions with matter and immateriality; the seen and unseen.

Within her practice, she explores the interplay between aesthetic and political valences, tracing the genealogies of what may otherwise be taken for granted. The founder of Oil Research Group (ORG), as part of her OVEREXPOSED residency for Sonic Acts, Gharavi delved deep into what she sees as ‘twin’ extractive commodities: oil and data. She is a former editor at The New Inquiry and lecturer at Northeastern University. Her publications include a translation of Syrian-Brazilian poet Waly Salomão’s Algaravias: _Echo Chamber_ (2016) and her own poetry volume _The Distancing Effect_, published the same year. Exhibitions, performances and screenings include Nottingham Contemporary, Serpentine Cinema, Framer Framed, Art Dubai, New Museum, Triple Canopy and many more. She completed a PhD in Comparative Literature and Film and Visual Studies at Harvard University, where she was Lecturer in History and Literature from 2012 to 2017.
[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/wcncnd/?hl=fr)

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Louis Braddock Clarke at Night Air: Melting Cores, OT301 on 31 March 2022. Photo by Pieter Kers.

content.text_block: **Louis Braddock Clarke** works as researcher and creative practitioner interpreting notions from domains of art, geography, physics and philosophy.

His multi-disciplinary  approach unfolds as an experimental inquiry blending together scientific and conceptual theories. Seeking out concealed obscurities lurking in daily life, he utilises cartographic language, new materialist thought and modes of peripheral vision. Braddock Clarke’s relationship with the geographical arts is embedded in his formative years in Cornwall, UK where he was surrounded by moorlands, granite, shifting isolines, tin mines and trans-Atlantic cable systems. These Earth energies have become paramount to his ongoing research methods relating to technologies and terrains. In their collaborative project _Out of Focus_, Braddock Clarke and Zuzanna Zgierska seek to interpret notions of research, design, philosophy and science.

[Website](https://louisbraddockclarke.co.uk/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/louisbclarke/)

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Zuzanna Zgierska. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Zuzanna Zgierska** is a cross-media designer with a strong interest in media theory.

he makes science-fiction objects, which challenge the tender interfaces between the human and the technical. Her research invites to view technology in a non-hierarchical, non-binary way: beyond the cold tokens of 0 and 1. Zgierska has exhibited worldwide, and her visual and written work has been published in an array of design magazines. In their multi-disciplinary project _Out of Focus_, Zgierska and Louis Braddock Clarke seek to interpret notions of research, design, philosophy and science. Unless caught red-handed hacking a bean sorting machine, Zgierska can be found extruding screen surfaces into portions of edible substance or chasing lightning storms across industrial deserts.

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Sam Lavigne. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Sam Lavigne** is an artist and educator who plugs into the interlocking interfaces of data, surveillance and policing, as well as natural language processing and automation.

From publishing a database of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) employees in response to the Trump administration's family separation policy, to _White Collar Crime Zones_ — a re-appropriation of a predictive policing algorithm — his work harnesses digital tools such as apps and information mining. These online interventions reveal the often opaque political and economic conditions moulding computational technologies. He has exhibited at the Whitney Museum, Lincoln Center, New Museum, Ars Electronica and IDFA Doclab, among others.

[Website](https://lav.io)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/samlavigne/)

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Farah Fayyad. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Farah Fayyad** is a graphic designer and printmaker focused on Arabic typography and bilingual publication design.

In 2018, along with her screen-printing mentor and master printmaker Salim Samara, she co-founded Nice Nice Prints, a studio, shop, and workshop space in her hometown of Beirut. Drawing on another apprenticeship, one with master calligrapher Mokhtar El-Baba, her work involves a lot of experimentation and play with the Arabic script. Fayyad is currently based between Beirut and Amsterdam, and recently completed an MFA degree at the Sandberg Instituut. In this context, she co-founded Typofiction, an open platform to research and experiment with typography, with a special focus on non-Latin scripts. In 2020, Fayyad was a finalist for the sixth edition of the Jameel Prize: Poetry to Politics.

[Website](http://www.farahfayyad.com/)


[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/farahfayyad/)

attributes.title: Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.image_caption: Miyuki Daorana. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Miyuki Daorana** was born and raised in Qaanaaq, the most northern city in Greenland, and the capital city of Nuuk.

Having lived amongst the natural landscape of Greenland her entire life, Daorana’s practice and research  is embedded in indigenous values and traditions of her Inuk community. Daorana collaborated with **Louis Braddock Clarke** and **Zuzanna  Zgierska** on the project _Hard Drives from Space_, commissioned for Sonic Acts Biennial 2022. She is studying for a BA in Anthropology at Aarhus University. 

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/miyukidaorana/?hl=en)

Extractive Archives: Conversation and Book Launch

content.text_block:
The Sonic Acts Biennial Symposium, _Leaving Traces_, opens a forum in which to feel out and become attentive to pollution’s invisible, yet harmful touch. Toxicity takes on many forms and shapes, but is mostly targeting the poorest in our societies – in places where infrastructures are ‘leaky’, regulations are hidden under layers of corruption (or simply too expensive), and interest for manufacturing toxicity runs high. These processes are not spectacular, nor are the structural inequalities a strong focus of our policies, so instead, the destructive trace of toxicity enacts damage soundlessly. 
 
Toxicity is always manufactured. Its history – a narrative of legislations, regulations, technologies and infrastructures that are designed and created with a permission to pollute. Those processes are always material and specific – related to particular human and nonhuman bodies, to landscapes, food, seas – and when untangled, one will usually find a destructive melange of interests, growth, extraction, exhaustion, privatisation and so on, at their core.    
 
Speaking of the many faces of toxicity – from fossil fuels to plastic, from nuclear energy to chemical pollutants – the Symposium will stage real stories and events of exposure. It will also try to think about strategies that may help us out of the ecological mess. Since Leaving Traces mostly features an array of artists, researchers, curators, designers and scholars that are actively rethinking our relation to the climate and our planetary legacies, the programme will also reflect on the role and importance of art in the climate crisis. Thinking about ‘leaving traces’ not just as the material act of spreading toxicity, but as art’s potential to reach out and act as a disruptive force in the world. 

If pollution is about leaving traces, so is the act of making them visible.

content.text_block:
# _Leaving Traces_ is structured in three panels on both Saturday and Sunday, with more than 20 international artists and scholars presenting their research at Likeminds. 

Each evening after the talks, the audience is invited to digest toxic entanglements and messy stories about climate emergencies through sound performances, concerts and films featuring an exciting lineup of artists. Tuning into the siren calls that warn us about disasters happening over geological timescales, the _Preemptive Listening_ and _Breathtune_ evening programmes – running Saturday at Likeminds and Sunday at Singelkerk – breathe new life into silenced or forgotten sound practices.
SATURDAY 15 OCTOBER

# _INFRASTRUCTURE OTHERWISE_
**11:00 – 13:00**

[Nerea Calvillo](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/nerea-calvillo)
• [Angeliki Balayannis](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/angeliki-balayannis)

Moderated by Mirna Belina

When infrastructures and bureaucratic spectacles perform well, they tend to fade into the background, and it becomes difficult to perceive how they shape our social relations and our lives. Through their respective engagement with air pollution and hazardous waste, **Nerea Calvillo** and **Angeliki Balayannis** invite us to consider the worlds these structures, protocols and practices sustain, asking how we can provoke different ways of sensing and reimagining our toxic reality.

content.title: Angeliki Balayannis: Public Experiments in Chemical Regulation

content.image_caption: Field notes, Angeliki Balayannis.

content.text_block:
# _BODY BURDEN / SITES OF REPAIR_
**14:00 – 16:15**

[Antonia Alampi](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/antonia-alampi)
• [Dani Admiss](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/dani-admiss)
• [Mary Maggic](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/mary-maggic)

Moderated by [Natalie Dixon](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/natalie-dixon)

From carbon emissions to plastic, hazardous waste and endocrine-disrupting chemicals, this panel thinks about artistic practices that make visible the complex relations of toxicity. Speaking about specific sites, communities, actions, and bodies, curators **Antonia Alampi** and **Dani Admiss**, along with artist and scholar **Mary Maggic**, demonstrate how platforms, exhibitions, collaborative projects, and ‘workshopologies’ can be used as sites to acknowledge and question the ‘slow violence’ of pollution.

content.title: Antonia Alampi: ‘Everywhere is a here, isn’t it?’ On Toxic Entanglements
Dani Admiss: Sunlight Doesn’t Need a Pipeline
Mary Maggic: Performing the Sublime Sea of Co-Mattering

content.image_caption: _The Toxic Consultancy_, Mary Maggic.

content.text_block:
# _A TROUBLE WE TRAVEL_
**16:30 – 18:00**

[Sophie Dyer](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/sophie-dyer), [Sasha Engelmann](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/sasha-engelmann)
• [MELT (Loren Britton, Isabel Paehr)](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/melt)

Moderated by Margarita Osipian

In their collaborative work, duos **Sophie Dyer** and **Sasha Engelmann** (open-weather), as well as **Isabel Paehr** and **Ren Loren Britton (MELT)** work on imaging and reimagining the time(s) of climate crisis. The first talk uses satellite signal to collectively imagine the planet, weaving together a feminist image of the Earth. In their talk, MELT trouble normative notions of time within climate change discourses, making time and space for crip, trans*, and kinship time – which are usually not pictured in the ‘normative’ image of the climate crisis.

content.title: Sophie Dyer, Sasha Engelmann (open-weather): when we image the earth, we imagine another
MELT: not a point we meet but a trouble we travel

content.image_caption: Storm Eunice, open weather.

content.text_block: SUNDAY 16 OCTOBER

# _CLIMATE IMAGINARIES AT SEA | REHEARSING DISASTER_
**11:00 – 13:00**

[Aura Satz](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/aura-satz)
• [Thomas Lamers](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/thomas-lamers) from Collectief Walden, with [Annelinde Bruijs](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/annelinde-bruijs) and [Dominic Kraemer](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/dominic-kraemer)
• [Mikki Stelder](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/mikki-stelder)
• [Daphina Misiedjan](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/daphina-misiedjan)

Moderated by [Laura Cull Ó Maoilearca](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/laura-cull)

Water. A transformative being. It affects everything it comes to pass on its way and is affected by what it encounters. Relearning the language of her Indigenous community, Robin Wall Kimmerer is well aware how many things are considered beings. One would not say ‘a bay’ but: ‘being a bay’. Sometimes water would be a river, sometimes a sea, it could also be a tsunami, a life source, an obstacle, a habitat... In this panel water transforms into different beings, as it flows past the different lenses through which various artists-researchers explore sea level rise – encountering human-made structures and non-human animals, resistance and embrace. 

The panel is curated in collaboration with an ARIAS coalition, Climate Imaginaries at Sea, coordinated and organised by Nienke Scholts.

Presentations are accompanied by songs from Collectief Walden’s _Songs for the Rising Water_, performed by singers Annelinde Bruijs and Dominic Kraemer.

content.title: Aura Satz: The Future Waters of the Storm Surge
Daphina Misiedjan: The Right to Water

content.image_caption: _Visual Methodologies Collective_. Generated with DiscoDiffusion.

content.text_block:
# _SITUATING FUEL_
**14:00 – 15:30**

[Maryam Monalisa Gharavi](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/maryam-monalisa-gharavi)
• [Kyveli Mavrokordopoulou](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/kyveli-mavrokordopoulou) • [Agnès Villette](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/agnes-villette)

Moderated by Margarita Osipian

As it becomes apparent that humanity’s future depends on its ability to transition away from polluting energy resources, the round-the-clock discussions about energy usage often elicit the individual in such a way that turning the lights on can constitute an ethical dilemma. In a world where we cannot personally choose a form of energy production that does not inflict significant harm, fuel situates us in relation to the world. Through a close look into oil and nuclear energy, this panel showcases the complex and extensive ways in which specific energy systems have shaped the economic, political, and cultural frames that orient our worlds.

content.title: Maryam Monalisa Gharavi: Dirt, Debt, Death, Data
Kyveli Mavrokordopoulou, Agnès Villette: Transient Marshlands, Permanent Progress – Geographies of Uncertainty

content.image_caption: Gravelines, Agnès Villette.

content.text_block:
# _MATTER, MOISTURE, HEAT: WHAT WE DO WHILE WE WAIT_
**16:00 – 18:00**

[Ola Hassanain](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/ola-hassanain)
• [Nishat Awan](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/nishat-awan)
• [Kent Chan](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/artists/kent-chan) 

Moderated by [Ameneh Solati](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/ameneh-solati)

Through their artistic and scholarly practices, **Ola Hassanain**, **Nishat Awan**, and **Kent Chan** imagine new vocabularies to describe sites of devastation, climate catastrophes, and crisis. Their research focuses on how architecture, cartography, and images capture the narrative implications created by Europe’s colonial history. The panel opens up questions about practices that make space to engage with the ramifications of extractive and toxic colonialism.

content.title: Ola Hassanain: Spatial Acts – Geographies of Absence and Waithood
Kent Chan: Five Stories on Heat

content.image_caption: _Topological Atlas_, Nishat Awan.

content.text_block: **Áine O’Dwyer** is a composer and performer residing between Ireland and the UK.

Her work is informed by both the conceptual concerns of sound-art and traditional compositional techniques, embracing the broader aesthetics of sound and its relationship to environment, time, audience and structure. The notion of place stands as a cornerstone of O'Dwyer’s practice, a compositional methodology in which the relation between situated speaking and real-time listening is fully embraced. O'Dwyer has performed her work internationally, and her recorded releases include _Music for Church Cleaners_ (2015), _Locusts_ (2016), _Beast Diaries_ (2017), _Gegeinschein_ (2016), _Gallarais_ (2017), and _Poems for Play_ (2018) published on her publishing imprint _Cloch_. In 2019, O’Dwyer performed _Time Time Time_, an operatic ensemble work written by Jennifer Walshe and Timothy Morton, which premiered at Muziekgebouw aan 't IJ as part of Sonic Acts Festival.

[Bandcamp](www.aineodwyer.bandcamp.com)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/aine-o-dwyer)

content.image_caption: Kali Malone at Sonic Acts Academy 2020. Photo by Pieter Kers.

content.text_block: **Kali Malone** is an American-Swedish musician best known for her compositions for pipe organ, choir, chamber music, and electroacoustic formats.

Malone’s repetitive and durational work interweaves synthetic and acoustic instrumentation, using highly specific tuning systems to craft work with stunning depth of focus. She has performed live extensively, and, in addition to commissioned projects and residencies including Ina GRM, Berlin Monom & Funkhaus, The Richard Thomas Foundation, MACBA, and Orgelpark; Malone collaborates and performs with various artists, including most recently Drew McDowall, Caterina Barbieri, Stephen O’Malley, Ellen Arkbro, Puce Mary, Zach Rowden, Leila Bordreuil, and Lucy Railton. Based in Stockholm, she released the album _The Sacrificial Code_ in 2019, and is the co-founder of the record label and concert series XKatedral.

[Website](https://kalimalone.com)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/kali-malone)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/hotscorpions/?hl=fr)

content.image_caption: Lucy Railton. Photo by Camille Blake.

content.text_block: Berlin and London-based cellist **Lucy Railton** has been an active performer, music producer and composer for over a decade, releasing albums on Modern Love, Editions Mego — GRM Portraits, PAN with Peter Zinovieff, and Takuroku.

Having emerged from a long-term engagement with classical and contemporary music, her practice exists between modern instrumentalism, electroacoustic composition, improvisation and expressive musique concrète. Over the years Railton has engaged with a range of interdisciplinary collaborations, and tours internationally as a solo performer or in collaboration with musicians and artists from a range of disciplines, most recently Rebecca Salvadori, Farida Amadou, Catherine Lamb, Kali Malone, Khyam Allami, Kit Downes and Stephen O’Malley. In 2016, Railton presented _Unknown_ in collaboration with Russell Haswell, a Sonic Acts commissioned work drawing on the pair’s time in the industrial and natural surroundings of the Barents Region.

[Website](https://lucyrailton.com/)

[Bandcamp](https://lucyrailton.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Bloedneus & de Snuitkever. Photo by fabononthemoon.

content.text_block: The work of Brussels-based sound artist and researcher Lukas de Clerck as **Bloedneus & de Snuitkever** is centred around the Aulous, an ancient-Greek double reeded double pipe extinct for over a millenia.

This speculative reimagining of the Aulous is inevitably auto-didactic, and De Clerk engages in both solo and collaborative forays into these sound-worlds. In both his solo performances as Bloedneus & de Snuitkever — and as part of the duo Ï Î with the violist Victor Guaita Igual  — De Clerck embraces the tension between the extra and the ordinary. Through his use of recognizable, almost everyday sounds, and by putting actions like gargling, whistling and sneezing in an artistic context, De Clerck creates connections between the audience and its spatial environment.

[Website](https://lukasdeclerck.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/declercklukas/)

content.image_caption: Ale Hop. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Ale Hop** is the moniker of artist, researcher, and experimental multi-instrumentalist Alejandra Cárdenas.

Beginning her career in the 2000s underground scene of Lima and now based in Berlin, Cárdenas has developed a complex repertoire of unorthodox guitar techniques, psychedelic drones, and visceral live performances. Her approach to the subjects on her albums is deeply studious, constantly shaped by her background as an interdisciplinary researcher. Cárdenas holds a BA in Art History, a Master's in Sound Studies, Postgraduate Degree in History of Science and Technology, and is currently pursuing a PhD at Berlin University of Arts. She has edited two volumes of the publication _Border-Listening/Escucha-Liminal_ on decolonial, non-western perspectives on sound and listening, and is co-founder of the Berlin-based festival Radical Sounds Latin America.
[Website](https://alehophop.com/cv/)

content.image_caption: Tatiana Heuman. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Tatiana Heuman** is a producer and drummer working between Argentina and Europe.

Influenced by her early work in the free improvisation band _Ricarda Cometa_, Heuman’s solo electronic music project_ QEEI_ carefully balances impulse, empowerment, chaos, and sensitivity — these elements standing as core touchstones within her work. Following the release of two EPs, Heuman released her first album _›QEEI‹_ in 2018 with the label Astro Nautico. In the following years, Heuman has performed regularly, in addition to organising workshops and laboratories through her position as a Deep Listening facilitator. Heuman’s second studio album will be released later this year.

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/qeeiqeei/?hl=de)

[Website ](https://www.tatianaheuman.com/)

content.image_caption: Kali Malone, Lucy Railton and Stephen O'Malley. Photo courtesy of the Artists.

content.text_block: **Stephen O’Malley** is a guitarist, producer, composer, and visual artist who has conceptualised and performed in drone and experimental music groups for over two decades.

O’Malley’s wildly prolific practice — most notably his projects including _SUNN O)))_, _KTL_, and _Khanate_ — is defined by its remarkable breadth, complexity, and collaborative approach. He has worked with a wide range of experimental figures including Scott Walker, Gisèle Vienne, Dennis Cooper, Alan Moore, Alvin Lucier, Fujiko Nakaya, and Jim Jarmusch; and has worked with experimental music research centres including IRCAM, INA-GRM, and EMS in Stockholm among others. In addition to his recorded work, O’Malley has been a vigorous live performer since 2003, his hypnotic performances featuring a reverberating fog of electric guitar minimalism.

[Website](https://stephenomalley.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/stephenomalley74/?hl=de)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/stephen-omalley)
# EXHIBITION

Expanding from Sonic Acts' long term research focus on the implications of climate crisis, _one sun after another_ traces the inextricable nature of pollution and time. Unfolding in several places, the exhibition and its public programme of events engage with ecology across vast scales.

Taking its name from a poem in Etel Adnan’s powerful book _The Arab Apocalypse_ (1989), the biennial exhibition gestures toward the passing of time, but also carries traces of _Bhagavad Gita_, referenced by Robert Oppenheimer after witnessing the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ‘If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst at once into the sky, that would be like the splendour of the mighty one. I am become Death, The Shatterer of Worlds.’ Drawing upon this sublime, all-subsuming vision, one sun after another attends to slow, accumulative violence as it makes its imprint on futures yet to come. Touching on deep, real, geological time, the programme embraces nonlinearity, fluctuation and porousness, making space for leaks. Permeable to hope, the figure of the ever-dawning sun glows without burning, permeating warmth, fueling imagination and propagating life.

content.image_caption: _Gauge_, Danny Osborne, Patrick Thompson, Alexa Hatanaka, Sarah McNair-Landry, Eric McNair-Landry, Erik Boomer, and Raven Chacon. Photo by Erik Boomer.

content.text_block: Contemplating multiple incarnations of time, _one sun after another_ listens to an immersive aerial choir of bees, follows a microbe embedded within lithium traveling from a Chilean mine to a digital device, and plunges into deep time through lead-encased nuclear coconuts from the Bikini Atoll. Artistic research traces the lineages of exhaust produced by oil and other extractive economies, while in other places it speculates over Greenland’s mineral deposits, now made accessible by melting ice. In the Canadian Arctic, visual narratives on monumental ice walls come and go with tidal movements, soundtracked by a cacophony of environmental field recordings. Against the din, visitors are welcome to a joyful meditation about presence, sensing and bending time, before drifting downstream, where the exhibition stretches time even further. Diving under, performative and installative artworks explore toxic cycles of water and stretch inner time with hybrid instruments and sub-aquatic amplification.

## PUBLIC PROGRAMME

The exhibition is complimented by a public programme of a variety of events, emanating across W139 and Zone2Source in Amsterdam. Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.
→ [Find out more about the public programme](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/public-programme)

_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

→ [Read through the Inner Ear(th) programme here](https://pdfhost.io/v/iUue4sUGj_Inner_Earth_Programme) (PDF)

content.text_block: As part of his practice, artist and cultural coordinator **John Grzinich** draws together sound, moving images, site-specificity and collaborative social structures.

Composing, performing and exhibiting since the mid 1990s, the focus of his work in recent years has been to combine sonic encounters and listening practices with various media. The resulting audio-centric works seek to challenge ingrained anthropocentric perceptions of terrestrial existence, discovering ways of attuning differently to landscapes and non-human entities. In addition to an impressive array of composition recordings, Grzinich’s work has resulted innumerous performances and projects throughout Europe and the US. Grzinich coordinates activities for the artist-run organisation MoKS and is currently a visiting Associate Professor at the Estonian Academy of Arts.

[Website](https://maaheli.ee/main/)

[Bandcamp](https://maaheli.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: Cesar Majorana. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: **Cesar Majorana** is a performer, presenter and artist working with writing, video and fragrance.

His work explores themes of digital media, internet culture, metaphor and memory; playfully rupturing the distance between artwork and viewer. Majorana graduated from Sandberg Institute in 2021 and his work has been on display at NPO3, Van Gogh Museum, IFFR and Rijksmuseum.

[Instagram ](https://www.instagram.com/cesarforever/)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/cesarforever)

_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

Walking In the Midst of It All
l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block:
Sound installation\
2021

This seed, or semilla, marks the beginning of something that grows in time, like an idea, like a movement. _Semilla_ is a small artefact, a sounding capsule containing a speaker and an mp3 player. Meant to be buried in the ground during a ritual, _Semilla_ is offered to the Earth as a symbolic act of resonance and active protection. From the underground, a subtle sound piece will emerge. This piece is composed with the resonant frequency of our planet. It is a resonant object that protects the place where it is buried as it produces noise and unwanted vibrations that render the ground unsoundable for geophones; extractive telluric sensors used by oil and gas companies to find new places for extraction.

content.image_caption: Nicole L'Huillier. Photo by Patricia Dominguez.

content.text_block: **Nicole L’Huillier** is a transdisciplinary artist from Santiago, Chile.

Through sound, vibrations, resonances, and multiple transductions, her work explores more-than-human performativity — from microscopic to cosmic scales; rituals of membranal and resonant architectures; as well as vibration and sound as construction materials for spaces, collectivity, identity, and agency. She has performed and exhibited widely at institutions including the Guggenheim Museum, Venice Architecture Biennale, Sónar +D, Ars Electronica, Institute of Contemporary Art Boston, SXSW, and Bienal de Artes Mediales Chile alongside many others. Currently based in Boston, L’Huillier completed a PhD in Media Arts & Sciences at MIT in 2022. She was recently selected for a residency at Transmediale and La Becque.

[Website](https://nicolelhuillier.com/)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/nico_lh/)

content.text_block: Getting our hands, eyes and ears dirty, _Practicum_ is a collaborative workshop series organised by Sonic Acts that focuses on applied knowledge, making from research and learning together.

These gatherings are artist-led and emphasise collaborative, hands-on learning: attuning and creating together in ways that entangle modes of perception, production and knowledge-creation. 

Continuing from our yearly programme, _Practicum_ resumes in full force for Sonic Acts Biennial 2022, welcoming artists, performers and researchers from across our exhibition, sound art, and symposium programmes. Each workshop features a separate open call with a different set of parameters.

attributes.title: From Listening to Sampling: IMC Weekendshool Workshop
l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block:
Welcome to [l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/l-a-g)!

Soundcamp collective and radio artist Kate Donovan host an open radio space and workshop-hub at the Homebase in Het HEM, with microphone and transistor building, dusk listening and fieldwalks, tuning to live sounds of the site.

**Tune into the 58 hour-long broadcast online via the play button at the top of sonicacts.com from Friday 7 October to Sunday 9 October.** The transmission is aired from the Homebase situated in the central hall of Het HEM, the Huiskamer and at various movable listening points dispersed around the Hembrug site.

_l a g_ occurs as an unpredictable ghost in the live archive of streams, as sounds move and appear out of place. lt brings stutters, drops or echoes that can put us into close contact with both what just occured and is about to.

# Contribute your own! Join in the stream below:

content.url: <iframe id="irc" height="500px" width="756px" frameborder="0" border="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="default" src="https://irc.soundtent.org/?&theme=soundcamp_irc_v1_white#acousticommons"></iframe>

content.text_block: The Soundcamp programme has been devised and curated specially for the Sonic Acts Biennial.

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block: **Soundcamp** is an arts cooperative based in London, Crete and The Hague, working on transmission ecologies ranging from DIY broadcasting devices to public sound and radio projects.

As part of the Acoustic Commons network, Soundcamp coordinates the long-form radio broadcast Reveil, in addition to an annual series of sound and ecology events on Dawn Chorus. In 2020, Soundcamp initiated the Creative Europe small cooperation project: _Acoustic Commons_, in partnership with arts organisations in Europe and Japan. Recent projects include _As if radio.._ at COP26 Glasgow, _Meet Me On The Radio_, _Biosphere Open Microphones_, and the portable audio system _PITCH_. With expertise in environmental sound, transmission art and participatory technologies, Soundcamp regularly organises workshops and exchanges as part of a socially engaged practice.
[Website](https://soundtent.org/soundcamp_about.html)

content.text_block: Getting our hands, eyes and ears dirty, _Practicum_ is a collaborative workshop series organised by Sonic Acts that focuses on applied knowledge, making from research and learning together.

These gatherings are artist-led and emphasise collaborative, hands-on learning: attuning and creating together in ways that entangle modes of perception, production and knowledge-creation. 

Continuing from our yearly programme, _Practicum_ resumes in full force for Sonic Acts Biennial 2022, welcoming artists, performers and researchers from across our exhibition, sound art, and symposium programmes. Each workshop features a separate open call with a different set of parameters.

content.text_block:
Welcome to [l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/l-a-g)!

Soundcamp collective and radio artist Kate Donovan host an open radio space and workshop-hub at the Homebase in Het HEM, with microphone and transistor building, dusk listening and fieldwalks, tuning to live sounds of the site.

**Tune into the 58 hour-long broadcast online via the play button at the top of sonicacts.com from Friday 7 October to Sunday 9 October.** The transmission is aired from the Homebase situated in the central hall of Het HEM, the Huiskamer and at various movable listening points dispersed around the Hembrug site.

_l a g_ occurs as an unpredictable ghost in the live archive of streams, as sounds move and appear out of place. lt brings stutters, drops or echoes that can put us into close contact with both what just occured and is about to.

# Contribute your own! Join in the stream below:

attributes.title: l a g – An Experiment in Ecological Radio

content.text_block: **Soundcamp** is an arts cooperative based in London, Crete and The Hague, working on transmission ecologies ranging from DIY broadcasting devices to public sound and radio projects.

As part of the Acoustic Commons network, Soundcamp coordinates the long-form radio broadcast Reveil, in addition to an annual series of sound and ecology events on Dawn Chorus. In 2020, Soundcamp initiated the Creative Europe small cooperation project: _Acoustic Commons_, in partnership with arts organisations in Europe and Japan. Recent projects include _As if radio.._ at COP26 Glasgow, _Meet Me On The Radio_, _Biosphere Open Microphones_, and the portable audio system _PITCH_. With expertise in environmental sound, transmission art and participatory technologies, Soundcamp regularly organises workshops and exchanges as part of a socially engaged practice.
[Website](https://soundtent.org/soundcamp_about.html)

content.text_block: # EXHIBITION

Expanding from Sonic Acts' long term research focus on the implications of climate crisis, _one sun after another_ traces the inextricable nature of pollution and time. Unfolding in several places, the exhibition and its public programme of events engage with ecology across vast scales.

Taking its name from a poem in Etel Adnan’s powerful book _The Arab Apocalypse_ (1989), the biennial exhibition gestures toward the passing of time, but also carries traces of _Bhagavad Gita_, referenced by Robert Oppenheimer after witnessing the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ‘If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst at once into the sky, that would be like the splendour of the mighty one. I am become Death, The Shatterer of Worlds.’ Drawing upon this sublime, all-subsuming vision, one sun after another attends to slow, accumulative violence as it makes its imprint on futures yet to come. Touching on deep, real, geological time, the programme embraces nonlinearity, fluctuation and porousness, making space for leaks. Permeable to hope, the figure of the ever-dawning sun glows without burning, permeating warmth, fueling imagination and propagating life.

content.image_caption: _Gauge_, Danny Osborne, Patrick Thompson, Alexa Hatanaka, Sarah McNair-Landry, Eric McNair-Landry, Erik Boomer, and Raven Chacon. Photo by Erik Boomer.

content.text_block: Contemplating multiple incarnations of time, _one sun after another_ listens to an immersive aerial choir of bees, follows a microbe embedded within lithium traveling from a Chilean mine to a digital device, and plunges into deep time through lead-encased nuclear coconuts from the Bikini Atoll. Artistic research traces the lineages of exhaust produced by oil and other extractive economies, while in other places it speculates over Greenland’s mineral deposits, now made accessible by melting ice. In the Canadian Arctic, visual narratives on monumental ice walls come and go with tidal movements, soundtracked by a cacophony of environmental field recordings. Against the din, visitors are welcome to a joyful meditation about presence, sensing and bending time, before drifting downstream, where the exhibition stretches time even further. Diving under, performative and installative artworks explore toxic cycles of water and stretch inner time with hybrid instruments and sub-aquatic amplification.

## PUBLIC PROGRAMME

The exhibition is complimented by a public programme of a variety of events, emanating across W139 and Zone2Source in Amsterdam. Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.
→ [Find out more about the public programme](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/public-programme)

content.text_block: As part of his practice, artist and cultural coordinator **John Grzinich** draws together sound, moving images, site-specificity and collaborative social structures.

Composing, performing and exhibiting since the mid 1990s, the focus of his work in recent years has been to combine sonic encounters and listening practices with various media. The resulting audio-centric works seek to challenge ingrained anthropocentric perceptions of terrestrial existence, discovering ways of attuning differently to landscapes and non-human entities. In addition to an impressive array of composition recordings, Grzinich’s work has resulted innumerous performances and projects throughout Europe and the US. Grzinich coordinates activities for the artist-run organisation MoKS and is currently a visiting Associate Professor at the Estonian Academy of Arts.

[Website](https://maaheli.ee/main/)

[Bandcamp](https://maaheli.bandcamp.com/)

content.image_caption: FARWARMTH. Photo by Xipipa.

content.text_block: **FARWARMTH** is Afonso Arrepia Ferreira, a young musician who creates vast, deeply emotional and orchestral electro-acoustic pieces.

Feeding on the constant experimentation and ‘emotional exchange’ encountered in the collaborative practices of both duos HRNS and Purga, and the artistic collective 00:NEKYIA – the work of FARWARMTH reveals a performative insight impossible to accomplish alone. Texturally vivid, his recent ventures include _Momentary Glow_, released on the acclaimed British label Planet Mu in 2020, and _A Blue Wind Is Now_ on the ecstatic Soul Feeder in 2022. 

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/farwarmth)

[Bandcamp](https://farwarmth.bandcamp.com/)

content.text_block: **Saranghwae** is a fluid art collective that engages in active exchanges between creators at the crossroads of art, science, and technology.

During 2022, all members of Saranghwae including **Sunjeong Hwang, Junsoo Kim, So Young Lee, Suhun Lee, Gyuchul Moon**, and **[Mint Park](https://www.sonicacts.com/community/mint-park)**, have been working together for the collaborative project _Being as Praxis_, seeking to free their practices from pre-existing systems, genres, or forms of audiovisual results. Taking place between Seoul and Amsterdam, Saranghwae wishes to rediscover techne with the local communities, not as a set of devices or strategies but as an innovative tool for understanding cosmo-technic diversity and inclusivity. 


[Website](http://www.saranghwae.com/)


[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/saranghwae.archive/)

content.image_caption: Marcin Pietruszewski. Photo by Kamila Lozinska.

content.text_block: **Marcin Pietruszewski** is a composer and researcher engaged in sound synthesis and composition with computers, exploring specific formal developments in the tradition of electroacoustic music and contemporary sound art.

Pietruszewski works in composition, pluriphonic installations, and radio productions – and his work often features synthetic sound, algorithmic systems, and the integration of scientific formalisms as compositional materials. Marcin Pietruszewski has exhibited at Edinburgh’s West Court Gallery, Remote Viewing in Philadelphia and the ICA in London, and his work has been commissioned by CTM Festival, ZKM Karlsruhe and Deutschlandradio Kultur. His collaborative projects include the sound installation _Auditory Scene Resynthesis as Cochlear Wavepackets_ with Jan St. Werner and _NORMIFICATION_ with Florian Hecker. _NORMIFICATION_ was released on Presto!? Records in 2022. 

[Website](https://www.marcinpietruszewski.com/)

[Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/marcin_pietruszewski)

content.image_caption: HC Gilje. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: Interdisciplinary artist **HC Gilje** has moved between installation, experimental video, live performance and set design since he graduated from the Academy of Fine Arts in Trondheim in 1999.

During his decade-long collaboration with Sonic Acts, HC Gilje has worked on the Dark Ecology project; has premiered and presented work including _Blink_ (2010), _Revolver_ (2013), _Rift_ (2017), and _Radiant Live_ (2019);  publishing work on his long-term project _Conversations with Spaces_ (2017). Gilje was a member of the video-impro trio 242.pilots and was visual motor of dance company Kreutzerkompani. He has screened his work internationally and continues to perform live — collaborating with **Maja Ratkje** and **Justin Bennett** and creating projections and set designs for theatre and dance.



[Website]( www.hcgilje.com)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/hc_gilje/?hl=fr)

content.image_caption: Tomoko Sauvage. Photo by Leo Lopez.

content.text_block: **Tomoko Sauvage** is a musician and sound artist best known for her experiments with hybrid instruments combining water, ceramics, sub-aquatic amplification and electronics.

Her research is grounded in live-performance practices that embrace the unpredictable dynamics of materials. Incorporating ritualistic gestures, she playfully improvises with environments, using chance as a compositional method. Her performances and installations have been presented at RIBOCA, V&A Museum, Manifesta, Roskilde Festival, Sharjah Art Foundation, Centre Pompidou Metz and Nyege Nyege Festival, among others. Recorded in a water tank in Berlin, utilising self-invented ‘natural synthesisers’: porcelain and glass bowls, filled with liquid and amplified by hydrophones, her third solo album _Fischgeist_ was released in 2020. Sauvage lives and works in Paris.
[Website](https://o-o-o-o.org/)

content.text_block: # EXHIBITION

Expanding from Sonic Acts' long term research focus on the implications of climate crisis, _one sun after another_ traces the inextricable nature of pollution and time. Unfolding in several places, the exhibition and its public programme of events engage with ecology across vast scales.

Taking its name from a poem in Etel Adnan’s powerful book _The Arab Apocalypse_ (1989), the biennial exhibition gestures toward the passing of time, but also carries traces of _Bhagavad Gita_, referenced by Robert Oppenheimer after witnessing the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ‘If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst at once into the sky, that would be like the splendour of the mighty one. I am become Death, The Shatterer of Worlds.’ Drawing upon this sublime, all-subsuming vision, one sun after another attends to slow, accumulative violence as it makes its imprint on futures yet to come. Touching on deep, real, geological time, the programme embraces nonlinearity, fluctuation and porousness, making space for leaks. Permeable to hope, the figure of the ever-dawning sun glows without burning, permeating warmth, fueling imagination and propagating life.

content.text_block: Contemplating multiple incarnations of time, _one sun after another_ listens to an immersive aerial choir of bees, follows a microbe embedded within lithium traveling from a Chilean mine to a digital device, and plunges into deep time through lead-encased nuclear coconuts from the Bikini Atoll. Artistic research traces the lineages of exhaust produced by oil and other extractive economies, while in other places it speculates over Greenland’s mineral deposits, now made accessible by melting ice. In the Canadian Arctic, visual narratives on monumental ice walls come and go with tidal movements, soundtracked by a cacophony of environmental field recordings. Against the din, visitors are welcome to a joyful meditation about presence, sensing and bending time, before drifting downstream, where the exhibition stretches time even further. Diving under, performative and installative artworks explore toxic cycles of water and stretch inner time with hybrid instruments and sub-aquatic amplification.

## PUBLIC PROGRAMME

The exhibition is complimented by a public programme of a variety of events, emanating across W139 and Zone2Source in Amsterdam. Join us for tasting sessions with **Leanne Wijnsma**, scented interventions by **Cesar Majorana**, live performances by **Loma Doom** and **G**, soundwalks led by **Tomoko Sauvage** and **Enrico Malatesta**, a meditative gathering with **MELT**, guided tours with Sonic Acts curators, listening sessions with **Félix Blume**, panel discussions and publication launches, and much more throughout Sonic Acts Biennial 2022.
→ [Find out more about the public programme](https://sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/public-programme)

content.image_caption: Lucky Dragons. Photos courtesy of the Artists.

content.text_block: **Lucky Dragons** is an ongoing collaboration between artists **Sarah Rara** and **Luke Fischbeck**.

They research forms of participation and dissent, purposefully working towards a better understanding of existing ecologies through performances, publications, recordings, and public art. The name Lucky Dragons is borrowed from the fishing vessel caught in fallout from American H-bomb tests in the mid-1950s, an incident which sparked international outcry and gave birth to the worldwide anti-nuclear movement. In 2021, they were selected as participants for Sonic Acts’ OVEREXPOSED residency programme, and have presented their work in a wide variety of contexts, including REDCAT, LACMA, MOCA and The Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, the Centre Georges Pompidou, 54th Venice Biennale, Documenta 14, the Whitney Biennial among many others.

[Website](https://luckydragons.org/)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/luckydragons)

_Inner Ear(th)_ presents a wide range of concerts, sound transmissions, installations, workshops and field explorations. Resonating with the complex histories of Het HEM – the former munitions factory – the programme excavates the multiple ecologies intertwining the geographies of the inner ear and earth through the reverberations of spatial sound. Within the cavernous walls, the contaminated soil of the nearby shock forest and docklands of the North Sea Canal, _Inner Ear(th)_ carves out a space for exchange at the unstable border of the natural and artificial. At such meeting points, where vibrations echo off the eardrum, transmitter, object or entity, the Biennial programme brings into focus a collective listening practice that explores our capacity to resonate.

On the first floor, the Exhibition Space hosts several performative spaces spread in between the gigantic girders. There, a radical sound diffusion system _Acousmonium_ will project both live performances and works from the archive. In the intimacy of the Black Box and Dark Room, the audience will be invited to experience various sonic provocations and audiovisual stagings, many of which are premieres. 

Beginning each day from 12:00, an array of installations, soundwalks and the [Soundcamp](https://www.sonicacts.com/biennial/biennial-2022/programme/inner-earth/soundcamp) programme – located in Homebase – are free of charge for anyone who wants to participate in the programme. Concerts and performances can be accessed with a Biennial passe-partout, weekend pass or day ticket.

→ [Read through the Inner Ear(th) programme here](https://pdfhost.io/v/iUue4sUGj_Inner_Earth_Programme) (PDF)

→ [View the Het HEM floorplan here](https://cms.sonicacts.com/public/uploads/SA_HEM_cover_V06_copy_2_bd2ef4c55d.jpg?w=1920&q=75)

content.image_caption: John Grzinich recording sound in Wadi Rum, Jordan. Photo courtesy of the Artist.

content.text_block: As part of his practice, artist and cultural coordinator **John Grzinich** draws together sound, moving images, site-specificity and collaborative social structures.

Composing, performing and exhibiting since the mid 1990s, the focus of his work in recent years has been to combine sonic encounters and listening practices with various media. The resulting audio-centric works seek to challenge ingrained anthropocentric perceptions of terrestrial existence, discovering ways of attuning differently to landscapes and non-human entities. In addition to an impressive array of composition recordings, Grzinich’s work has resulted innumerous performances and projects throughout Europe and the US. Grzinich coordinates activities for the artist-run organisation MoKS and is currently a visiting Associate Professor at the Estonian Academy of Arts.

[Website](https://maaheli.ee/main/)

[Bandcamp](https://maaheli.bandcamp.com/)
